Seruaūts borne in their maiſters houſes. Vernaculos, that is ſeruaunts borne at mine houſe. For the children of bondmen, which were borne at home, were called Vernaculi, which alwayes dyd ſeruice to that maiſter, whoſe bondman their father was, whether he were bought with money, or howſoeuer els he became bond. I bought ſeruaunts and maydens, that is to ſay, I was a notable huſband in gouernaunce of houſe & familie. I thought to rule my houſe according
to mine owne phantaſie and deuiſe. I gathered ſubſtaunce and treaſure. Whatſoeuer ornamentes and precious apparellings were to be gotten in any countrey, that I furniſhed my ſelfe with, to declare the pompe of my kyngdome, as great & rich kings vſe to doe.

div.head: I prouided me ſingers, and women playeng on Inſtrumentes, to make myrth and paſſe tyme.
div.p:
HEre is a great variaunce amōg Grā mariens what Schida, and Schidoth is. I trāſlated it, men and women daū ſers, but I like it not. I folow them in ye meane ſeaſon, that thinke they are inſtrumentes of muſike, and that becauſe of that is ſaid before, where he thus writeth: I prepared me men ſingers and womē ſingers, and things that might cheare and ſollace men, that is to ſay, noyſes of inſtruments. He doubleth this word Schida, Veſchidoth, becauſe perhaps hee would expreſſe the mutuall conſent and ſingyng by courſe that is amōg Muſitians. I was in great auctoritie or worſhyp &c. That is to ſay, all theſe thinges were moſt commodiouſly ordered
and diſpoſed afterward.What wiſdome Salomon vnderſtādeth in this place. And wiſedome remayned with me. He vnderſtandeth not ſpeculatiue wiſedome, but that wiſedome that conſiſteth in good ordering and gouerning theſe worldly affaires, wherein is included the diuine wiſedome. He confeſſeth that he had not onely abundaunce of thinges, but wiſedome alſo therwith, to adminiſter, rule, and gouerne all thinges well, which is the greateſt gift that God giueth man. But it had no ſucceſſe, becauſe he would haue all thinges, which he had ſo wiſely ordeined procéede after his owne deuiſe &c. where notwithſtandyng, this is the ſaying of all men in the world. It is not as it ought to be, becauſe they ſée many thinges wiſely appointed and ordeined & yet haue no ſucceſſe &c. The greateſt pointe of wiſedome therefore is to know this, that ſucceſſe foloweth not, but when God appointeth & that things are gouerned neither by counſell of the wiſe, nor by temeritie of the fooliſh.

div.head: And whatſoeuer myne eyes deſired, I let them haue it.
div.p:
The impediments of pleaſures.THat is to ſay, I went yet farther, and thought to enioye all the thinges. I
had prepared, but I was not permitted. I ment to make this my portion in this life, but God would not ſuffer me to order theſe pleaſures after mine owne deuiſe, hee alwayes put many ſtumbling blockes in my way. Whē I would haue enioyed my deſires, my gardens, the affaires of the kingdome called me backe, I was faine to ſit downe and giue ſentence accordyng to law and right, I had matters in ſuite to arbitrement, and to determine and take vp &c. Thus I was not able to take my paſtime as I deſired. This ſame very thing happeneth in our Princes, that when they purpoſe to take their delightes, ſome heauy occurrēce falleth out that diſturbeth their ioy, and cauſeth them to ſorrow. Thus doth God alwayes, to ſtoppe and hinder our deuiſes and appointementes. He giueth vs inough to vſe and make mery with, but hee will therewith haue vs to kéepe his Creatures purely and ſincerely in their owne libertie.

div.head: Loe all this was but vanitie, and vexation of mynde.
div.p:
IS not this a great vanitie, for a kyng that hath ſuch abundaunce of goodes,
and plenty of all things, and can not yet enioye any one thing of ſo many according to his owne deuiſe.We muſt enioye thynges preſent. And if he chaūce to enioye any of them, yet it is but by ſtealth. So vnable we are to gouerne, or comprehend thinges after our owne deſire. Let euery man therfore fréely enioy the thinges preſent euen as God ſendeth them. Let him ſuffer them to be taken away, and to be giuen him, to goe & to come, according to the Lordes pleaſure, when it is good. Let him thinke It may agayne turne to euill, and contrarywiſe, that hee wallow not and bee drowned in pleaſures, as the wicked vſe &c.

div.head: Nothyng of any value vnder the Sunne.
div.p: OF his own deuiſes man reapeth nothing but trauaile and miſery. The Creatures are good, but our deſires and deuiſes are vayne, which preſcribe vnto them boundes and rules, whereas they will not be ruled by vs.

div.head:
Then dyd I turne me, to conſider wiſedome, errour, and fooliſhnes. For what is hee among men, that
might be cōpared to me the kyng, in ſuch workes? And I ſawe that wiſedome excelleth fooliſhenes, as farre as light doth darkenes. For a wiſe man hath his eyes in his head, but the foole goeth in darkeneſſe. I perceaued alſo that they both had one end.
div.p:
BY an other experience he prooueth all thinges are but vaine,Wiſe mens deuiſes fruſtrated. I meane mans counſels and enterpriſes. Euen (ſayth hee) as it hath happened to me: ſo ſee I it happeneth to others alſo. My deuiſes, & wiſedome were fruſtrate & in vayne, and could not attayne to that ſucceſſe yt I wiſhed. The ſame I perceaued in others likewiſe. I looked vpon other mens wiſedome and folly, and compared them togither. I ſaw how ſome mē dealt very wiſely, & went about matters very prudently. I ſaw alſo fooliſh men and hare-braynes working without counſell, and yet their folly and temeritie was ſometime fortunate and had good ſucceſſe. Where the counſels of the wiſe came to no effect, and the wiſe men were moſt infortunate, in ſo much that this foole hardynes became a Prouerbe, Fortune
fauoreth fooles.

Examples. Cicero and Demoſthenes were moſt wiſe men, & had notably appointed their common weales, and made very good lawes, they thought alſo, yt they ſhould haue had good ſucceſſe, but it fell out otherwiſe, in ſomuch that the one ſayd of him ſelfe: O I that was neuer wiſe, and ſometyme iudged in vayne to be that I was not. O Citizēs, how much hath your opiniō of me deceaued you. &c. The other broken and worne with age and trauell, ſayd, that he wiſhed death rather, then to bee combred agayne with charge of publike affaires, him ſelfe hauing well tried that matters goe not according to the good counſels of the wiſe. Cōtrariwiſe Iulius and Octauius Caeſars, not alway followyng wiſe, but bold counſels, were much more fortunate. Philip kyng of Macedonia procéeded againſt Demoſthenes deuiſes, beyng him ſelfe alſo more fortunate then wyſe.The ſucceſſe is not aunſwerable, to wiſe mens deuiſes.

Surely their deuiſes and counſels were good, but ſo to vrge thē, to appointe ſo certeine a ſucceſſe of thē, was a vaine deuiſe. For matters will not be taken in
hand by mans deuiſe. To be brief matters goe not according to the counſell of ye wiſe, nor according heddynes of fooles, that the counſels of the wiſe might bée prooued fooliſh, that we ſhould not glory in our ſelues. Thus in warre ſtraitway the victory is not gotten, albeit the army be neuer ſo well appointed, & all thinges moſt wiſely forecaſt and deuiſed. As not many yeares ago, ye Frēch kyng thought to haue had a great victory agaynſt the Emperour, but it fell out contrary.

This hee ſaith therefore?Deuiſes are of men, but ſucceſſe of God. Thou ſéeſt that matters ſuccéede aſwel with fooles, as with wiſe men, ſo yt it might appeare there were no difference betweene a foole and a wiſeman, as touching ſucceſſe, yea that it might ſeeme there were no God that ſuffreth matters ſo vnaduiſedly to paſſe. But Salomon aunſwereth, no, but that wiſedome farre paſſeth fooliſhneſſe. True it is that mans wiſedome bryngeth not thinges to paſſe, but God doth it. God by his wiſedome can bring to paſſe what he will, but man can not. For God hath not onely wiſedome, but alſo a power to doe it, ſo that the thing which hee commaundeth muſt néedes ſuccéede.
This man can not doe. To conclude: Gods counſell is not deceaued but mens coūſels how wiſe ſoeuer they be, are deceaued. Therfore he ſayth very well:

div.head: And I ſaw that wiſedome excelleth fooliſhneſſe as farre as light doth darkenes.
div.p: WIſdome is very good, but becauſe it lacketh power and ſtrength, it can not bring thinges about, nor rule the ſucceſſe of them.

div.head: A wyſe man hath his eyes in hys head, but the foole. &c.
div.p: We muſt not put truſt in our owne deuiſes, and commit the ſucceſſe of them to God. I Sée verely that the lyke happeneth to them both. Our wiſedome deceaueth vs, our fooliſhnes deceaueth vs: yet wiſdome paſſeth fooliſhnes. To haue the eyes in the head, is an Hebrew phraſe, which wee commonly doe vſe to expreſſe thus. Hee that will playe at cheaſtes muſt not hyde his eyes in his purſe. Wherby we ſignifie that he muſt not onely be ſkilful in that play, but alſo haue a diligent eye and care to his play: So he ſayth here:

div.head: A wiſe man hath his eyes in his head.
div.p: THat is, they are not onely wiſe handlers of their matters, but alſo circumſpect and carefull about them, and ſée in déede how thinges ſhould be ordred, but can not perfourme and accompliſhe the effect. The foole hath not his eyes in hys forehead, becauſe he procéedeth raſhely, and at all auentures. Howbeit in déede on both ſides ye matter goeth by fortune, and chaunce, that is, God ruleth the ſucceſſe, & not according to our circumſpection or negligence. Sometimes they fall both, ſometyme they proſper both. But God will not that wee ſhall make any certayne rule thereof. For the creatures are not in our power, but in Gods, who graunteth vs the vſe of them, and by our meanes doth what pleaſeth hym. That we of our ſelues adde hereto, in going about to rule the vſe of them by our counſels and enterpriſes, is vayne. He ſchooleth vs therfore, not to truſt in our owne wyſdome and counſels, but to doe as occaſion ſerueth, and if it ſuccéede not, to commit it vnto God.

div.head: For what man is able to imitate the kyng that made him before. &c.
div.p: Hee that made vs, gouerneth vs.HEre by a goodly and apt paraphraſis, he deſcribeth god, as if he ſhould ſay: God is our king, he hath not onely made vs, but alſo continually gouerneth vs, ſo that all thinges happen to vs according to his will. He alone reacheth from the beginning to the end, neyther can any man hinder or ſtoppe his will & counſell. For this cauſe thought Salomon to call him a king rather then God. Some men haue wiſdome, ſome fooliſhnes, but no man can imitate his king, nor do that he doth. For what he appointeth commeth to paſſe, his will and counſell taketh effecte.

div.head: And made vs before (to ſay) that we were.
div.p:
THe like phraſe hath S. Paule: Who firſt gaue vnto him, and he ſhal be recompenced? Euen therfore as thys kyng ruleth and gouerneth, all thynges fall out. Hereby therfore he ſheweth that our deuiſes are of no value, becauſe we be made, and be not the kyng. God will not haue vs and his creatures to be ruled by our ſelues, but contrariwiſe, or els we ſhould be kynges and rulers ouer
God. Nothing ſuccéedeth after our wiſdome, or fooliſhnes, but many incurre diſpleaſure by fooliſhnes, and more by wiſdome, as euen the wyſeſt of all other men, Dion, Cicero, Brutus, Demoſthenes. &c. Becauſe God doth fruſtrate and delude mans counſels and deuiſes, to prouoke vs by all meanes to feare him, and to learne to let him alone with the gouernaunce of all thinges, and in nothing to preſcribe hym.

div.head: And I ſaw that the ſucceſſe of both theſe men were alike.
div.p:
THat is, I ſawe, they had both lyke fortune, that as little preuayled the wyſe man as the foole. That thinges are gouerned neither by wiſedome,Both wiſdome and temeritie, without Gods gouernaunce, is vnhappy nor fooliſhnes, although God ſuffer thinges to be done by them both, but no rule muſt be made thereof. For if our coūſell were of force, then ſhould it alway proſper. If fooliſhnes did hurt alwayes, then ſhould it neuer proſper. Marius, Antonius, & diuers other preuayled more by their temeritie and raſhnes, then Cicero dyd with his wiſdome. And a man ſhall no where finde more examples of mans fooliſhnes
and wiſdome, then among the Romaines and Gentiles. For among ye Iewes, warres were taken in hand for the moſt part, according as the prophets appointed, and God commaunded.

div.head: Then ſayd I in my mynde, if it happen vnto the foole as it doth vnto me, what neede I labour then any more for wiſdome? So I ſayde in myne hart, that this alſo was but vanitie.
div.p: We muſt not truſt in our own deuiſes.ANd theſe wordes tende to this ende, that we ſhould abſteine from affiaūce in our owne deuiſes. I (ſaith Salomon) gouerned my kingdome moſt wiſely, & I had a Lieftenant or preſident, which gouerned not ſo prudently as I, and yet had he good ſucceſſe. Since therfore I ſée fooles haue as good ſucceſſe, or better then I, why truſt I to myne owne counſell and wiſdome, encreaſing but my labour and ſorrow.

div.head: So I ſayd in mine hart this alſo was but vanitie.
div.p:
I Founde by experience, that neither wiſdome, nor raſhenes was to be truſted.
For before it was declared, that wiſdome paſſeth fooliſhnes, although things be gouerned neither by fooliſhnes nor wiſdome.Our affayres muſt be cōmended to ye kyng that made vs. We muſt holde therefore a meane betwéene both, we muſt commit our matters to the king which made vs. If he offer vs any commoditie, wée muſt vſe it: if he geue vs ought, we muſt take it: if he take ought from vs, we muſt ſuffer it. &c. Doe that thou art able, what thou canſt not doe, that let alone. Looke what thou canst not lift, let it lye. So my wiſdome ſhall be profitable vnto me, if I doe that I know pleaſeth God, and leaue to his ordering that he will doe by me. If we would thus doe, then ſhould we be wiſemen in déede.

div.head: For the wyſe are euer as little in remembraunce as the fooliſhe. For the dayes ſhall come, when all ſhal be forgotten.
div.p:
BOth that the wiſe man hath done and deuiſed by this counſell,All things through obliuion, are buryed & forgottē. and that the foole hath done through his fooliſhneſſe, whether it ſuccéeded well or euill, ſhal be forgotten. For neither they themſelues, nor other ſhall be the better for it, that
they may learne to committe all thinges vnto God, but their poſteritie ſhall follow their owne wayes, and not be content with the ordinaunces of their Aunceſtors, but ſéeke new deuiſes, lothyng that they haue, and ſéeking for that they haue not, dreaming thus. If it once ſucceeded well with me, it will doe ſo once agayne. If it did not before ſuccéede, it will now ſuccéede. We wil doe wiſelyer then they haue done before vs. &c.

Nothyng is of continuaunce in this world.Beholde the Romaines cōmon weale, how the Conſulles alwayes, and the Emperours afterwarde ſtill repealed their Predeceſſours Actes, diſdayning thinges preſent and paſt, and lookyng on thinges to come. Why therefore doeſt thou take ſuch care, as though thy poſteritie would like or allow that thou dooſt. It will not be. For that men haue, they reiecte as vnprofitable. &c. Therfore it is impoſſible, that thinges ſhould remaine in the ſame eſtimation wyth poſteritie, that they were in before.

Lycurgus. Lycurgus thought he had geuen ſuch lawes to the Lacedemonians, as they would haue kept till he had come backe agayne, that is, for euer. According to
the which deuiſe, he went his wayes, mynding to returne backe no more, hoping by this meanes, that his lawes ſhould be alwayes obſerued, but he nothing preuailed.

Auguſtus ſayd he had layd ſuch foundations of a common weale,Auguſtus. as he hoped ſhould ſtand for euer, but they that came after, turned all vp ſet downe. The people of Rome wiſhed the death of Nero, Nero. hoping they ſhould haue had a better cō mon weale. But afterward it went neuer the better with their commō weale. Salomon ſo gouerned his Realme that he thought it ſhoulde haue ſo continued ſtill,Salomon. and by and by after his death it was deuided.Roboam. For Roboam which ſuccéeded him, not content with his fathers wyſe gouernaunce of the kingdome, rent it in two partes.

And it commeth not onely thus to paſſe, in externe and ciuile matters, where ſuch fooliſhnes is the more tollerable, becauſe there is but the loſſe of thinges corporall, but alſo in religion,Alteration of common weales and religions. and in the word of God, where poſteritie alway neglecting the puritie of the doctrine left by our predeceſſours, ſéeke
newe inuentions, euen as they, which now the Goſpell is publiſhed, not content with the puritie of fayth, & doctrine of the Goſpell, raiſe newe diſputations about the Sacramentes, which when it hath béene of any continuaunce, newe ſectes will ariſe without ende. For the fleſhe can not be cōtēted with one plaine and true doctrine.

Salomon ſpeaketh not of perſons, but of thoſe things that men doe.Thou muſt vnderſtand that Salomō ſpeaketh not here of the perſons but of the things that men do, whether they be wiſe or fooliſh, becauſe they be neglected. The remembraunce of men indureth in bookes, but not in ordering of the commō weale, and matters are regiſtred and put in Recordes, but no mā careth or taketh héede to them, neither is poſteritie moued with the examples of their predeceſſours. Still they deuiſe new wayes and faſhions. That lyeth before them, is lothed, that they haue not is deſired. Briefly, to be content with thinges preſent, is playnely a gift of the holy ghoſt, a thyng impoſſible to the fleſhe, which alwayes forſaketh thinges preſent for thinges to come, and whiles it purſueth the one, it loſeth the other, defrauding it ſelfe of the
vſe of both. A couetous man lacketh aſwell that hee hath, as that hee hath not. And as it fareth with the couetous in money, ſo fareth it with all mankind in pleaſures and deuiſes &c. that is to ſay, they haue nothing though they haue all thing. Let Alexander Magnus ſtand for an example, whoſe mynde was not ſatiſfied after hee had conquered all Aſia. If this be true in outwarde thinges, what maruell is it in matters of the Goſpell? That we haue we haue not, becauſe our affection is not ſettled, but are deſirous of other thinges. On the other ſide Chriſtians haue all things, though they haue nothyng.

div.head: And the wyſe man dyeth as well as the foole.
div.p:
THe lyke ſaying is in the Pſalme 49. Wiſe men alſo dye and periſhe togither aſwel as the ignoraūt and fooliſh, and leaue their riches for other. &c. This alſo is to bee vnderſtanded of things that men doe. The wiſe mā dyeth for all his doynges aſwell as the foole. No man regardeth what they well ordeined. And when thou haſt done aſwell
as is poſſible, for thy reward, are all thy doynges diſdayned, or els thou art haniſhed or put to death &c. Yea many will contemne thine Actes and repeale them.

div.head: Wherefore I was weary of my lyfe becauſe I ſaw that all thinges done vnder the ſunne were naught. For all was but vanitie and vexation of mynde.
div.p:
THat is, whatſoeuer was done vnder the Sunne did much diſpleaſe mee, foraſmuch as it was naught elles but vaine labour and vexation. Not that Salomon wiſhed his death, but for that hee thought it was a miſerable caſe to leade a mās life in ſuch doings. Thus he meaneth: I became weary of it and ouerladen therewith. For who can ſuffer to haue nothing but labour in diuiſing and contempt after he hath done.What this phraſe, to lyue, ſignifieth. To liue, or life, after the phraſe of Scripture, ſignifieth to liue well and at eaſe. To leade a perfect life. Pſalme 22. No man hath quickened his owne ſoule, yt is whoſe ſoule liued not well. Thoſe that liue euill and a hard lyfe, as poore men that are oppreſſed and in miſery, and appointed
to dye. Of theſe it is ſayd in the ſcriptures, they liue not. Therefore he ſayth not, he deſireth death, but that this trade of life wherein men are ſo wearyed and vexed with their owne deuiſes, diſpleaſeth him.

Salomon meaneth that wee ſhould ſtand in a readines whether life or death betyde,How we muſt lyue. and calleth vs backe to the vſe of thinges preſent, becauſe we ſhould bee content with them without care of hereafter, and commit all thinges vnto God, who will worke by vs, as it were vnwitting to vs. Euē as the Oxe that treadeth out the corne and eateth, knoweth not what he doth, nor is carefull for his liuing or labour: ſo muſt wee doe, that God offreth vs, and ſuffer that hee will haue done. Yet all theſe thinges muſt be but as a morſell of bread, which we haue here on earth, that we looke not by our owne deuiſes to garniſhe this life, for then ſhall we alwayes bee vnquyet, as foloweth:

div.head:
And I was weary of all my labour which I had takē vnder the ſunne, becauſe I ſhould be fayne to leaue them to an other man that commeth
after me, who whether hee ſhal be a wiſe mā or a foole I know not. And yet ſhall he be Lord of all my labours.
div.p:
The life of man is miſerable.THis ſentence is all one with yt aboue. Salomon floweth in wordes, & copiouſly treateth of this place. Thus (ſayth he) I am weary of my life: for albeit I haue ordered all thinges after the beſt way that can be deuiſed, yet know I not whether mine heyre ſhall be wiſe or fooliſh. If he happen to be wiſe, hee will ſet light by that I haue done, and inuent an other thyng, ſeeyng I my ſelfe many times miſlike mine owne doinges, & am deſirous of other. If he be a foole, he will deſtroy that I haue done, and take as much paynes in pullyng downe, as I tooke in ſetting vp, according to the Prouerbe, One buildeth, another pulleth down. So Octauius Caeſar beautified the Citie of Rome, Nero defaced it. Pompey brought great maſſes of money into the treaſure houſe, meaning it ſhould ſerue for the benefite of the common weale. Caeſar after that tooke it away, and it became rather a deſtruction then any benefite to the commō weale. Therfore whether
mine heyre ſhall be wiſe or fooliſh, in vaine haue I trauelled, and ſpent my lyfe in vayne cares, hauyng an eye to thinges to come, and not vſing thinges preſent, and therfore he addeth:

div.head: So I turned me to refrayne my mynde, from ſuch trauell as I had takē vnder the ſunne. For ſo much as a man ſhould weary hym ſelfe with wiſedome, with vnderſtandyng, and induſtrie, & yet be fayne to leaue his labours to an other, that neuer ſwet for them. This alſo is a vayne thyng and great miſerie. For what getteth a man of all the labour & trauell of his mynde, that hee taketh vnder the ſunne, but heauines, ſorow, and diſquietneſſe all the dayes of his lyfe. In ſo much that his hart can not reſt in the night. This is alſo a vayne thyng.
div.p:
I Ceaſſed (ſayth hee) to take any more care for theſe worldly affaires.we muſt not be carefull for to morrow. This is the ſaying of a wiſe man whiche calleth backe his minde from cares, to reſt and quyet. I will be content with things preſent,
and I will doe and ſuffer forthwith that God willeth me, neither will I care for to morow. This is the concluſion which afterward he amplifieth copiouſly, ſaying:

div.head: For when a man hath wearied him ſelfe, with wiſedome, vnderſtandyng, and diligence &c.
div.p: HEre you ſée what he vnderſtādeth by wiſedome, not ſpeculation, but the rule and gouernaunce of matters, induſtrie, or congruence of doing, Induſtry or dexteritie in doyng of thyngs. When all things are done in order and in time. Euē as he appointed twelue Captaines ouer the land, their dyet, and horſes &c. This hee calleth to weary him ſelfe in wiſedome. This wearyſomnes and portion he leaneth to a man that hath taken no paines in the ſame, yea that more vnhappie is, to a man that careth not for it, and forgetteth it. When I haue taken all this paine ſaith hee, I leaue it to one that contemneth it, or ſpoileth it, which thing ſurely is a great vanitie.

div.head: For what getteth a man of all hys trauell &c. This is but copy &c. Nor can reſt in the night.
div.p: HIs hart is not at any reſt, no not in the night while he paineth him ſelfe, not onely in ye day time to bring his deuiſe trimely to paſſe, but when he hath finiſhed it, ſtudieth in the night, how to preſerue and encreaſe it.

div.head: Is it not better therefore for a man to eate and drinke, and his ſoule to be mery in his labour?
div.p:
THis is the principall concluſion,The principall concluſion of the whole booke. yea the coūſell of the whole booke, which he often hereafter repeateth. And this is a notable place for the expoūding of that is gone before, and that that followeth. Thus he cōſenteth with that that is ſayd afore. Theſe pleaſures are to bee cōdemned that we of our owne heades and deuiſe prepare for the time to come. Thoſe trauels and paines to be condēned which we vndertake of our owne phātaſie and braine. But the pleaſures and trauels that God ſendeth are good, & to be vſed as they come without care of pleaſure, or vexation after to enſue. But who cā thus doe. It is very well ſayd, but we doe not that that is ſo wiſely proponed, we heare it as though we heard it not, and ſée it as
though we ſaw it not, and no man followeth it. For we are drowned in ye care of making preparation and compaſſing of our owne affaires. Our hart cā brooke no good counſell, but is vexed euery day more and more. The godly caſt frō them all cares. All other men leade a diſquiet life, euen till they dye. He ſaith therfore:

div.head: I ſaw that this was a gift of God.
div.p:
True mirth or ioye is the gift of god. A Notable ſaying & ſingular doctrine, but yet he leſſe vrgeth this ſaying thē that before. Which commeth to paſſe by reaſon the affirmatiue mooueth vs not ſo much as the negatiue, euen as this affirmatiue: I am the Lorde thy God which brought thee out of the land of Aegipt, it is quickly ſayd, but it doth not much mooue vs. In the negatiue there is greater force. Thou ſhalt haue none other Gods in my ſight. &c. So in this place, he briefely handleth this affirmatiue. It is good for a man to eate and drinke. &c. but in the negatiue, he is very long to ſhewe and prooue vnto vs our folly; namely, that we nothyng preuaile with all our trauels & deuiſes, becauſe we are troubled
with cares, and vſe not thinges preſent. So vnto theſe groſſe headed men, it is requiſite he ſpake groſſely, and at large. For vnto wiſe men, all might be ſayd in one worde: The Lord himſelfe is thy God. &c.

div.head: For who hath eaten, or done more thinges abroad then I?
div.p: HE alleageth his experience. For if I which haue done ſo great thynges, and haue ſo abounded in all maner of riches, haue not atteyned to my wyſhe & deſier, how much leſſe ſhall other doe ſo, if God geue not mirth and ioye?

div.head: God geueth to the mā that is good before him, wiſdome, vnderſtanding, and gladneſſe. But vnto the ſinner he geueth wearines and ſuperfluous care, that he may gather and heape togither the thyng that afterward ſhalbe geuen vnto hym, whom it pleaſeth God. Wherfore, this alſo is a vanitie and vexation of the mynde.
div.p:
THat it is the gift of God to be cōtent with thinges preſent, he prooueth.
Becauſe it is geuen without any merits of ours going before,The godly vſe their goodes wt peace and myrth: but the vngodly haue no peace. to that man whom God lyketh. He deuideth the world into godly and vngodly. Vnto the godly, beſide the giftes that they haue lyke vnto others, chiefly prudence and wiſedome, is geuen mirth alſo, becauſe they be content with thinges preſent, they are not troubled with thoughtes and deſires of the minde as the wicked are. That they haue knowledge, and are wiſe in doyng their buſines. &c. their knowledge is in mirth and peace, but the wicked haue trouble and vexatiō, alwayes gathering togither more and more, and neuer be ſatiſfied. Moreouer, although they haue wiſdome and induſtrye, yet it is ſo mixt with ſorow, that they are rather a paine to them, ſo that they can not enioy their trauell, but till the ground and buylde, and other receaue the pleaſure and commoditie of it. But that the wicked trauell in and buylde, none vſeth well but the godly. So thoſe thinges that Princes gather togither, are the goods of the godly, becauſe they onely vſe them mearily and with thankes geuing, although they haue but a litle. The wicked haue
much, and yet they vſe it not, but haue therwith great care and vexation. To be ſhort, the godly truely haue the whole worlde, becauſe they haue ioye and tranquilitie. The vngodly in hauing it, haue it not. This is the vanitie that the vngodly haue.

div.head: The third Chapter.
To all thinges there is an appointed tyme, and a tyme to euery purpoſe vnder the heauen.
div.p:
ANd here Salomon (as hath béene declared before) ſpeaketh of mās workes, that is to ſay,All the workes of man haue a tyme to be begon, to be done, & to be finiſhed in. ſuch as are taken in hand of mans wiſdome and counſell. This the interpreters not marking, thinke that he ſpeaketh in this place of the corruptyng of Gods creatures. Thus therefore vnderſtand, that all mans workes and deuiſes haue their certaine and appointed ſeaſon of doing, beginning and endyng, beyond mans power & habilitie, ſo that he ſpeaketh againſt frée will, becauſe it is not in our power, to appoint ye tyme,
the meane, and the effect of our affayres, and that our enterpriſes and endeuours herein are vtterly fruſtrated, but that all thinges goe and come when God appointeth. This he proueth by the examples of mens workes, which are ordred beſide and aboue mans appointment, ſo that hereof he concludeth, that men are troubled in vaine with their owne deuiſes, and can bring nothing to paſſe, for all they can doe, vntill that time & houre commeth, that God appointeth. Hereto belongeth that ſaying in the Goſpell: The houre is not yet come. Agayne: A woman while ſhe is in trauell hath paine and ſorrow, becauſe her houre is come. Thus the power of God comprehendeth all thinges vnder their appointed houres and ſeaſons, ſo that no man can let or hinder them.

How we be rulers & Lordes of Gods creatures.But thou wilt ſay. How then is man made ruler ouer all thinges Gene. 2. if he be not able to gouerne them at his pleaſure, and to vſe them accordyng to his deſier? I aunſwere: we be ſo made gouerners of theſe creatures, as to vſe thē for the tyme preſent. But we are not able to rule them with our cares and trauels.
No man with all his deuiſes, can compaſſe any thing for the time to come. For he that is vncertaine of thinges to come, how can he take order for thinges to come. Therfore God will haue vs to vſe his creatures fréely, as he geueth thē, without preſcribing of tyme, meane, or houre. For theſe thinges are in ye hand of God, ſo that we muſt not thinke it is in our power, to vſe thinges when wee will, vnles he graunt it. For this cauſe Ieſus the ſonne of Sirach ſayth: God left man in the hand of his counſell, but he gaue him preceptes and commaundementes, whereby to moderate his deuiſes and doinges. &c.

div.head: All thinges haue their tyme.
div.p: THat is, their appointed houre and ſeaſon, which if man paſſe and goe beyond, and will bring all thinges about after his owne wayes and deuiſes, hée ſhall reape nought but vanitie thereof. Many men labour to waxe riche, but they preuaile not. Other are enriched, yea without any labour. Becauſe God hath appointed that houre, for the one, and not for the other.

div.head: And euery purpoſe. &c.
div.p: IN the Hebrew it is Hephetz, which commonly is tranſlated pleaſure, or deſire. Me thinketh it may handſomely be tranſlated delight, as in the 2. Pſalm: his delight is in the law of the Lord. For Hephetz ſignifieth, that which a mā doth apply himſelfe vnto, & deliteth in. That deſire that a man hath to fulfil the law. But euen herein alſo, all ye things that men wiſhe and deſier, they labour and would faine haue thē, but they vexe thēſelues onely, becauſe they can not attaine to that houre & ſeaſon, which they goe about to preuent, and therefore they get nothing. Therefore thinges muſt ſimply and plainely be committed vnto God, and we muſt vſe thinges preſent, and abſteine from deſier of thinges to come. And if we deale otherwiſe, wee ſhall reape nothing but labour & trauell.

div.head: There is a tyme to be borne, and a tyme to dye.
div.p:
Man is no Lord, but a bayliue of his lyfe.HE prooueth the thing he hath ſpoken by examples of mans deuiſes and occurrencies. Our birth hath his tyme, ſayth he, and likewiſe our death. And
euen as we haue not our birthes in our power, no more haue we our deathes, and yet nothing is more ours then our lyfe, and all our members, but onely to vſe them. But wee haue no power or Lordſhip geuen vs ouer thē, not for one minutes ſpace, and therfore in vayne we ſeeke to preſcribe them rules or lawes. The infant is in the hand of God, & can not be borne before his houre commeth. The women labour and are very carefull about the byrth of it, and tell when it will come, but there is no certainty in their ſaying. No more can we die, be we in neuer ſo extreame daunger and deſperation, but when our houre is come. Why then feare we death? Thou canſt liue no lōger then God hath appointed, nor dye any ſooner then he appointeth. For thus ſayth Iob. 14. Mās time is determined, and the number of hys monthes is with thee: thou haſt appointed hym his boundes, which he can not paſſe.

But thou wilt ſay,Euery mā is apointed his certein houre to dye in. many peariſhe wilfully, and through their owne temeritie, which might otherwiſe liue lōger. Some breake their owne neckes. &c.
Could they not haue ſaued their lyues? I aunſwere, No. God appointed that houre, thoſe meanes, and that kynde of death, as dayly experience teacheth vs. Some are deadly wounded, and are eaſely healed and liue, ſome other are ſcarſly ſcratched, and yet dye of it. The Aſtrologers aſcribe theſe thinges to the Planets, other attribute it to fortune. But the holy Scripture aſcribeth it vnto god, in whoſe handes are layde vp all the minutes of our liues and deathes, wyth whom it is all one, whether thou dye of a greuous wounde, or of a litle ſcratch, becauſe he will cōfound all mās wiſdom & deuiſes. But to ye true Chriſtians this is a great comfort, becauſe they know death is not in the power of Tyrauntes, nor of any creature, & becauſe they ſhuld not bee ouer carefull about death, but ſhould dye like children whē God ſo appointeth. Therfore as he pronounceth of the condition of our byrth and dyeng: euen ſo may we ſay of all other affaires of men, as it foloweth:

div.head: A tyme to plant, and a tyme to plucke vp.
div.p: THeſe be workes of mās lyfe, and yet no more in our power, then our lyfe it ſelfe. In the ſpring, we plant and ſet, in harueſt we pull vp againe. All things are to be done as God hath appointed & ordeined, and none otherwiſe.

div.head: A tyme to ſlea, and a time to heale: a time to breake downe, & a time to buylde, a tyme to weepe, and a tyme to laughe: a time to mourne, and a tyme to daunce: a tyme to caſt away ſtones, and a tyme to gather ſtones: a tyme to embrace, & a tyme to abſteine frō embracyng: a time to ſeeke, and a tyme to loſe: a tyme to keepe, and a tyme to caſt away: a tyme to reape, and a tyme to ſow: a tyme to keepe ſilence, and a tyme to ſpeake: a tyme to loue, & a time to hate: a time of warre, and a tyme of peace.
div.p:
TO this roll belongeth experiēce to be applied to the whole courſe of mans life. For here it cōmeth to paſſe,We muſt vſe ye goods that God hath geuen vs. that one ſoweth, another reapeth, one gathereth together, an other waſteth and ſpēdeth. To be brief. Euery worke of mans lyfe
hath his appointed ſeaſon out of ye which what ſoeuer man doth, hee laboureth in vayne & preuaileth not. There is a time to wéepe, & a tyme to laugh. Many times it chaunceth that when we meane to be meryeſt, ſome great trouble marreth all. Therfore myrth hath alſo her tyme and ſeaſon. Experience teacheth vs all theſe things, that we (I ſay) can do nothing accordyng to our appointementes, but as time ſerueth vs to do them. Therfore let vs not trouble our ſelues about thinges to come, but vſe thinges preſent.

div.head: What profite hath he that worketh of the thyng wherin he trauelleth?
div.p: THat is to ſay, vnles times and oportunitie ſerue him, he ſhal do no good. The maker of a thing hath nothing but his time and ſeaſon. Till this commeth, he can do nothing. If the houre be hit ſo doth he likewiſe hit it.

div.head: I haue ſeene the trauell that God hath geuen the ſonnes of men, to humble them therby.
div.p:
THis is a declaration of the thinges gone before. In all theſe thynges
ſaith hee, I haue ſéene that men can doe naught of them ſelues, vnles their houre be come. And they that wil preuent their houre are troubled with ſorrow & care: ſo that their own experience teacheth thē to abſteine from care for things to come, and to vſe thoſe thynges they haue.

div.head: For God hath made all thynges beautifull in their time and ſeaſon.
div.p: THis now is ye other part.God appointeth all men a tyme and ſeaſon. They that wayte not their time are troubled & vexed. Agayne, they that abide it, finde much comfort therein. For euery thyng that God doth, and that is done by God, the gift is pleaſaunt in his ſeaſon. That is: whē the hart is voyde of cares, & then hath ſome commoditie or pleaſaunt ſight happenyng to it, that greatly delighteth it. Therefore ſuch men reape pleaſure, where other gather affliction and vexation, bycauſe they doe their things in the tyme that God appointeth.

div.head: Alſo he hath ſet the world in theyr hart, yet can not man finde out the worke that God hath wrought frō the begynnyng to the end.
div.p: Men cānot enioye the things that god geueth them.THis is a confirmation of the thynges gone before. Although (ſayth he) God hath ſet the world in their hart, yet are they not able to gouerne it through their own coūſels. This is an Hebrue phraſe, to giue or ſpeake to the hart, for to giue or ſpeake fayre or mearily. This is it he would ſay. God doth not onely ſet the world in their power, wherby they may vſe the thinges preſent, but alſo ſetteth in their hart, that they may vſe it with pleaſure and ioye. That they may haue both ioye and pleaſure of it. And yet man knoweth not when his worke ſhall begin or end, when or how long he ſhall enioy it. Therfore man muſt be content, that hath the world in his vſe.

They that are content with their ſtate, vſe their goods preſent.Paule ſpeaketh in a like phraſe Act. 14. And ſurely he lefte not him ſelfe without witnes, in that he dyd good, and gaue vs rayne from heauen, and frutefull ſeaſons, fillyng our hartes with foode and gladnes. And in an other place: Which miniſtreth to vs all thinges abundantly. This ioy hath the Chriſtian and euery one might haue it, if he could be contented with things preſent. Well ſaith S. Hierome in his Prologue
vpon the Bible.The ſaying of S. Hierome. To him that truſteth in God, all the world is in ſtede of riches. But a faithleſſe body hath neede euen of an halfe peny, accordyng to the Prouerbe: A couetous body wanteth aſwel that hee hath, as that he hath not.

div.head: ¶ But man findeth not out the worke. &c.
div.p:
THat is to ſay, man can not know, would he neuer ſo much vexe him ſelf there about, when God wil do him good,Thinges to come, muſt be commēded to God, & things preſent muſt be enioyed. when to begin, or when to make an end. Euen as no man is able to ſearch out, or declare ye houre when any ſhal be borne, how long they ſhall liue, or when they ſhall dye, ſtudy they neuer ſo much. We muſt therfore ſay: Lord, it is in thy power to giue thinges for the time to come, in the meane ſeaſon I wil reioyce in that thou haſt giuē me, and in that thing yt is preſent. Thus ye other actiōs of mās life, wherof he hath rehearſed a great many, are not in mans power. For if it were, ſome men would alway make warre, other woulde alwayes geue themſelues to gaming, other woulde alwayes bée occupied in buylding &c. Becauſe many
men giue thē ſelues hereunto. Therfore all the world is ours, onely we muſt not preſcribe God any time or manner how we will vſe them. I will not (ſaith God) be meaſured according to your deuiſes, for ſo ſhould all thinges be at your commaundement, and I alſo. He concludeth therfore as in the chapiter gone before.

div.head: And I know that there is nothyng good in them, but to reioyce and to doe good in his lyfe. And alſo that euery man eateth and drinketh, and ſeeth the cōmoditie of al his labour, this is the gift of God.
div.p:
What is moſt pleaſaunt to a man.THeſe thinges are well inough vnderſtode by the premiſſes. For this hee meaneth to ſay. There is nothing better for a man in theſe miſerable caſes, then to enioye the thinges preſent, and to be mery at his hart, without care and ſtudy of thinges to come. But this is the gift of God that a man can ſo doe. I am able (ſaith he) to teach ye what to do, but to do it my ſelfe, or to giue the power to do it, I am not able. He ſheweth both what is to be done, & where yt we muſt doe is to be receaued. He declareth that our cares
doe onely vexe and moleſt vs, but he teacheth vs that we muſt call vpon God, to remoue away theſe cares, and to giue vs good ſucceſſe and peace of minde.

div.head: I know that whatſoeuer God ſhall doe, ſhall be for euer: to it can no man adde, and from it cā none diminiſh. For God hath done it, that they ſhould feare before him.
div.p:
THis is to ſay,Gods workes are ſtable, but mans fraile & vnſure. I ſaw that all thinges that God doth, endure for euer. As for our workes, they be vaine and vncertaine. And this antitheſis or coūterpoint is to be wel marked. God only (ſaith he) can bring his purpoſe to paſſe, & appoint them in their tymes. Looke to whom he giueth the gift to enioy thinges preſent, he hath it. He is faithfull and ſure. That he geueth, no man can take away. If he giue life, no man can bereue vs of it, although the world and Sathan rage and raue. For he is ſure and euerlaſting. If he giue me good eyes, I ſhall kéepe them notwithſtanding Sathan would throwe all the duſt of the earth into them. If he wil graunt me ſtrong, and whole armes and legges, no man ſhall be able to take
them from mee. All our workes haue their tyme and houre ordeyned, which we can not appointe. Who then? God himſelfe appointeth the houre, and not fortune and deſtinie, as ye Philoſophers ſuppoſe. When he ſuffreth the houre to come which ordeyned it, then it cōmeth.

Therefore will God haue the workes of men to be vncertaine, becauſe, he he will be feared.Why then doth he ſo trouble mē with this vaine cogitatiō, reſeruing all times and ſeaſons to himſelfe? Therfore (ſaith Salomon) becauſe he would be feared, becauſe we ſhoulde not be raſhe in our buſineſſes, nor attempt any thing proudly and preſumptuouſly as of our ſelues, as Paule alſo teacheth vs: Walkyng in feare, knowing that it is not in mans will and endeuour, becauſe it is hee that worketh both the will and perfourmaunce. Hee that beléeueth theſe thinges, that is, that our affayres lye not in our owne power, hee doth nothing raſhely. He attributeth all to God that worketh it, and looketh for it at his hād. If he graunt it, he enioyeth it, if not, hée can be contented to lacke it. If he take it from him, he beareth it. Thus remaineth the glory of God, the humbling of our ſelues, and the true worſhip of God
in vs. For this is the feare of God, to ſet God in our ſight, to know that he is the beholder of all our workes, and the author of all proſperitie and aduerſitie.

div.head: That that hath beene, is alſo nowe, and that that ſhall be, hath beene already, and God requireth the thinges that are paſt.
div.p:
BEfore in the firſt Chapiter, he ſayde:The difference betweene the workes of God, and man. What is that that hath beene? that that is to come. &c. Becauſe in that place, he ſpake of mens workes and doinges, here in this place, he ſpeaketh of Gods. Mans mynde can not content it ſelfe with the thinges it hath, but ſtill wiſheth for the thinges to come. And when thoſe thinges are come that it wiſheth, it is not contented neither, but againe deſireth other thinges, ſo that it is neuer ſatiſfied. For this is the condition of the hart of man, alwayes to gape after future thinges, and neuer to bee filled. But God procéedeth after a cōtrary ſort and maner. For that that hath béene with him, is yet ſtill: that is to ſay: bee turneth him not to thinges to come. For thus ſaith the Scripture of him. He behelde
all the thinges he made, & they were very good. God reſteth in the worke that he maketh, and doth not ſo hop and leape to the deſier of thynges to come, as mans mynde doth. And they ye walke according to Gods appointment, doe euen lyke: their heades ſtretch not to future thinges, conteining things preſent. The godly perſon laboureth & worketh after a conſtant ſort, and conſtantly enioyeth the thing that God ſendeth.

div.head: Becauſe God requireth the things that are paſt.
div.p:
Gods workes & mans are not all one.HE compareth (as I ſayd before) gods doinges and maners togither wyth mans, by way of an Antitheſis, or coū terpointing. Our ſtudy is to neglect and ſet light of the thinges we haue, and to beholde and waite for the things we ſhal haue. But God purſueth the thyng that is, and perſeuereth in his worke, that ye thing he doth, may be ſtable and cōſtant. In lyke ſort are the ſtudies of thoſe that are godly. This is it he would ſay. Euē when man goeth about to let or hynder Gods worke, yet God ſéeketh how to defend and maintaine that worke that mā
goeth about to hinder and let. &c. God appointed Dauid to be king: Abſolon perſecuted him, and went about to let it. But God agayne reſtored that that Abſolō would haue letted. The things that God appointeth are not ſo inconſtāt and fickle as mans deuiſes. For God doth not abhorre and lothe hys owne counſels.

div.head: Moreouer, I ſaw vnder the Sunne, the place of iudgemēt, where was wickednes, and the place of iuſtice wher was iniquitie. And I thought in myne hart, God will iudge the iuſt and the wicked: for there is a tyme for euery worke & purpoſe.
div.p:
WHat ſhould I ſpeake of the vices & vanitie of mans deuiſes,Vnrighteouſnes in common weales. where as euen in the place of iudgement, that is, where iuſtice and lawe ſhould be adminiſtred, wicked men and vngodlines doe raigne. And Salomō doth not ſo much complayne, that vngodlynes is in the place of iudgement, as that it can not in that place be amended and corrected: as though he ſhould ſay. All thinges are vtterly ſo vayne, that the care of correcting
this vnrighteouſnes of officers, doth no good. When I ſaw this wickednes, I thought to correct it, but I founde that I was not able, till God would correct it. So our Prince Frederike was wont to ſay:The ſaying of Frederike Duke of Saxony. The longer I gouerne, the leſse I knowe how to gouerne. Againe: Where ſhall I at length finde him that I may trust? Sée in the courtes of all princes, how notwithſtanding there be diuers good men that wiſhe well to the common weale, and géeue good counſell thereunto, yet wyll there be alwayes ſome founde, that will daſhe and trouble all their counſels and deuiſes. Such therefore, and ſo great is the malice and naughtines of man, that man is not able to amende and correcte all men.

Salomons meaning therfore is, that if a man would breake his brayne to correct all men; he ſhould reape nothing but trauell and care of his doing. Therfore the matter muſt be committed to God, and ſuch ſtones taken and lifted vp, as we are able to reare and welde. That that will not be reared let it lye ſtill. I (ſayth he) that was a wiſe king, ouer an holy people, and a diligent ſetter forward
of righteouſnes, was compelled to ſuffer wicked perſons to bée in publike office. For although I had diſplaced and put certaine of them out of office: yet alwayes would ſome other proue the like. Then how will it fall out with other Princes. Therefore it is the beſt to doe that God appointeth, and the reſt to cō mit vnto him, which in his tyme ſhall iudge both the righteous and vnrighteous. For men will not, nor can not, although they were neuer ſo willing.

div.head: There is a tyme for euery worke and purpoſe.
div.p: ALl things (ſayth he) haue their time. Vices can not be corrected, vntil that appointed time & ſeaſon come. In vaine therefore doe we goe about to preuent that time, by our amending of all things afore that tyme. In ſo much that my enterpriſe ſuccéeded not in myne officers. I did what I was able, I corrected as much as I could, the reſt I committed vnto God.

div.head:
I conſidered in myne hart the ſtate of the children of men, that God
hath purged them: yet, to ſee to, they are in themſelues as beaſtes. For the condition of the children of mē, and the cōdition of beaſtes are euen as one. As the one dyeth: ſo dyeth the other.
div.p:
A cōplaint of the confuſion of mans lyfe to the outward ſight, agaynſte which the worde of God muſt be ſet. For ther is a difference betwene the godly & vngodly.THis place is ſomewhat obſcure, not ſo much of it ſelfe, as through the default of the expoſitours, which greatly trouble themſelues, while they ſuppoſe for the moſt part that Salomō ſpeaketh in the preſence of the vngodly: but thys is but a colde inuention and ſuppoſall, although a receaued. Mée thinketh the ſence is to be taken plainely. He maketh a maner of a Sermō or collation of mās wayes and deuiſes, that they are all but vayne. At length he commeth to ye trouble and vexation, that is in officers, how they which ought to be a rule & enſample to other, are alſo vaine them ſelues. So of ſpeciall propoſitions going before, he deſcendeth to generall. What ſhall I ſay or ſpeake of ſingular eſtates, of perſons, when we be all as beaſtes? Is not this a miſerable caſe among mē? Wherin differ they from beaſtes, which haue no remembraunce or féeling of God?
But here riſeth a queſtion. Wherefore he compareth men with beaſtes, whereas before he taught vs there was a religion and feare of God, and a life euerlaſting after this life. Which thing hath moſt troubled the expoſitours. The aunwere is ſhorte. The interpretours doe not here marke the ſcope and drift of the booke, neyther doe they remēber (which thing yet Salomon doth often repeate) that he ſpeaketh of the things vnder the Sunne, which in the newe Teſtament, and more commonly is ſayd, in ye world. For this booke maketh a difference betwen a godly life, & the life that is led in the world, or vnder the ſunne. To haue a chearefull hart, and to ioye in ye things that God géeueth vs, in the feare of god, is nothing of the worlde, but a gifte of God from heauen, and aboue the ſunne. But to be vexed with the care of worldely thynges, is a beaſtly ſtate and condition.

div.head: The ſtate (or faſhion) of the children of men.
div.p:
IN the Hebrew toung this word is of a large ſignification, but as it is here
vſed, it ſignifieth a faſhion, māner, order, conuerſation, as in the Pſalme. 109. Thou art a Prieſt for euer, after the order, or faſhion of Melchiſedech. I thinke it ſignifieth properly a guiſe, or manner. The Epiſtle to the Hebrewes doth notably handle this worde of the Pſalme. For euen as Melchiſedech (ſaith he) had neither father nor mother &c: euen ſo and in like ſorte &c. It commeth of this worde Dabar, whiche is a thing or cauſe. It ſignifieth therfore a faſhion, or manner, ſo that the meanyng is: I conſidered in myne hart the mā ner or faſhion of mans life. After what ſort men behaue them ſelues on earth. What ſucceſſe men haue in their doynges, and how they behaue them ſelues.

div.head: For the condition of the childrē of men, and of beaſtes are all as one.
div.p: THat is the like things happen to mē, as doe vnto beaſtes. He meaneth mā paſſeth vp & down this life as the beaſtes doe, and getteth no more by his life, then doe the beaſtes.

div.head: As the beaſtes dye, ſo dye men.
div.p: HE ſpeaketh of the houre of death,The houre of death is vncertaine. not of the kinde. That is, as the houre of the beaſts death is vncerteine, ſo is the houre of mās. A beaſt knoweth not whē he ſhal fall ſicke or be whole, or when he ſhal dye, no more knoweth a man. Why therefore are we ſo proude? Since wee know no more when we ſhall dye, then doth the beaſt?

div.head: For they haue all one breath, and there is no excellency of mā aboue the beaſt. For all is vanitie. All goe to one place, & all was of the duſt, and all ſhall returne to the duſt.
div.p:
THis place can not be wreſted to the mortalitie of the ſoule,It ſeemeth that men & beaſtes haue both one kinde of death, but there is yet a great difference: for ye ſoules are immortal, & the bodies of men ſhall be reuiued. becauſe he ſpeaketh of things vnder the ſunne. Certes the worlde can not perceaue, nor beleue that the ſoule is immortall. But if a man regarde the likenes that Salomō ſpeaketh of, man dyeth lyke as the beaſt doth, & breatheth euen as the beaſt doth. In a kynde of likenes therfore we be all one. The Philoſophers reaſoned in déede of the immortalitie of the ſoule, but ſo coldly, that they may ſéeme to haue done nothyng but trifle, but Ariſtotle
chiefly ſo diſputeth of ye ſoule, that in all places hee taketh circumſpect héede that he reaſon not of the immortalitie therof, and would not expreſſe what his meanyng was. Plato reported rather what other men ſayd, then what him ſelfe thought. For the immortalitie therof cā be prooued by no reaſon of man, becauſe it is a thing beyond the ſunne, to beleue the ſoule is immortall. In the world it is not ſéene, nor vnderſtanded for a certeinty, that ye minde of mā is immortall.

div.head: All goe to one place &c.
div.p: All thyngs liuyng ſhall returne into duſt of ye earth.THat is, vnles the Lord gaue his ſpirite vnto man no man could ſay, that man differed any thyng from the beaſt. For man and beaſt are made both of one matter, of duſt, and returne agayne alſo into that duſt. And the returning agayne into the ſame thing or place, is an argument of likenes betwene man and beaſt. Not that it is ſo in déede, but becauſe the worlde according to the likenes falling out betwen them ſo ſuppoſeth, & can not ſuppoſe otherwiſe. Therefore to hold or beleue otherwiſe, is required an higher matter, then is the world.

div.head: Wherby he tryeth them.
div.p: THe Hebrew worde ſignifieth to purifie or chooſe. God ſayth he,Men in their miſeries are cō forted with hope of eternall lyfe. ſuffreth both man and beaſt, all after one ſorte and faſhion to come into the world, and to goe out of the worlde. But this he ſuffreth to trye whether men will onely regarde theſe outward appearaunces, and be led with the argumentes of the wicked, & beleue none other thyng. The godly by theſe thinges are ſo exerciſed that their fayth is the more increaſed. They paſſe out of this world in déede, as doe the wicked and the beaſtes, but in their hart and ſpirite they are comforted and at quyet.

div.head: Who knoweth whether the ſpirite of man aſcende vpwarde, and the ſpirite of the beaſt deſcend downward vnto the earth?
div.p:
TEll me plainely (ſaith he) of one mā,The vngodly doubte of the immortalitie of the ſoule. not of the godly, but of thoſe that are vnder the ſunne, or in the world, which can affirme that the ſoule ſhall liue after this life, conſidering he ſéeth the lyfe of mā and beaſt to differre in nothing. For aſſoone as their breath faileth them, they dye both. This no man knoweth. But in
that we know it, we know it not as mē, but as the ſonnes of God, and aboue the ſunne, as who haue our conuerſation in heauenly thinges, and belong vnto heauē. In the world this knowledge is not, neither is there any peace, but all things come to paſſe as with beaſtes. There were in Gréece moſt excellent wyttes, which yet neuer vttered any ſound learning touchyng this matter. Lucian a mā of a ſharpe and pleaſaunt wyt diſputeth earneſtly hereof, but ſcoffing onely at the Philoſophers opinions of the ſoule.

div.head: ¶Therefore I ſee that there is nothing better, then that a mā ſhould reioyſe in his affaires, becauſe that is his portion. For who ſhall bryng him to ſee, what ſhall be after him?
div.p:
The opinion of godly men which beleeue the immortalitie of the ſoule.THis is the opinion of thoſe that be godly, for they haue taken holde of this doctrine. The vngodly are vexed with the likenes and ſimilitude betwene vs and beaſtes, and can finde nothing but vanity in their trauels. For this doctrine they neither know, nor beleeue, for reaſon can not perſuade it them. And by this place is all the whole heape of Philoſophers
conuinced, gathering many things together touching the immortalitie of ye ſoule, which they beleue not. This therfore is the portion of the godly, to enioy the things preſēt, and not to be troubled with things to come. But this commeth not to paſſe vnder the ſunne. They that doe otherwiſe clogge them ſelues with double incommoditie, they enioy not the thinges preſent, nor attaine not to the thinges to come, and it happeneth vnto them as vnto Aeſopes dog, that ſnatched at the ſhadow, & loſt his meate. So theſe men loth the thinges preſent, and ſéeke for other thinges. Thus hetherto Salomō hath diſcourſed moſt in generalities of ye vanities of this worlde: now follow certein particulars.

div.head: The fourth Chapiter.

So I turned and conſidered all the oppreſsions that are wrought vnder the ſunne: & behold, the teares of the oppreſſed, and none cōforteth them, nor deliuered them out of the hādes of their oppreſſours, to comfort them.
div.p:
A cōplainte of the miſerie of mans lyfe from which wt out ye helpe of God, hee can not be deliuered. HEtherto Salomon hath rekoned the vaine deuiſes of men. By reaſon that God hindreth and letteth them, namely how thoſe things onely, which God doth and appointeth, atteine & come to their end, and can not be letted or hindred. Now henceforth he rekoneth the impedimēts of mens deuiſes, that is, the meanes and cauſes, whereby God vſeth to reuoke vs from our counſels and deuiſes, compelling vs to vſe thoſe thinges that we preſētly haue. I ſaw (ſayth he) that neither Princes nor Magiſtrates are hable to take awaye violence and iniurie from among men, yea God ſetteth naughty diſpoſed mē in their way, from whom they can not be deliuered. Dauid beyng a very good prince minded to profite and doe good to the commō weale, but Ioab and Abſolon did hinder & let him.Sclander, or reproche. He went about to make Ioab out of the way, but he was not able. Thus haue Princes their hinderers and diſturbers, whō yet they are compelled to ſuffer, and by whō God hindreth the deuiſes of the wiſe. I ſaw alſo how Iudges were corrupted & bribed,Oppreſſion of good mē. and how tyrantes oppreſſed the
widowes, and fatherles children &c. And ſurely greater is the violence and fearcenes of man, then any man is able to rule and correct, but God alone.

div.head: Wherefore I prayſed thoſe that are dead, aboue thoſe that are lyuyng, and I coūted him that yet was vnborne better then them both. For he hath not ſeene the euill workes that are wrought vnder the ſunne.
div.p:
HEre againe theſe fine witted mē diſpute,If ye godly had no conſolatiō, it were better not to be borne, then to lyue in ſo great miſerie. as though Salomon ſpoke like an vngodly man, that preferred the dead before the liuing. Albeit Auguſtine treating of ye place of S. Iohn: (It had been better for that man that he had neuer beene borne.) ſayth: It were better for a man to be in euill caſe, then to haue no being at all. Howbeit theſe men deale ſophiſtically. Damned & myſerable creatures thus thinke and iudge, as Salomon here ſayth: For vndoubtedly, they had rather not to be at all, then to be continually ſo tormented, and thys in déede were better for them. Therfore Salomon ſayth well in this place. If we conſider the miſeries & afflictions of mē,
and haue reſpect onely to this life, we ſhall praiſe the dead, rather then the lyuing. A man were better to be dead, then to ſée ſo great miſery and calamitie. He ſpeaketh nothing of ye iudgemēt to come, but of thinges done vnder the Sunne: where it is better not to be, then to ſée ſuch afflictions of men. Which thing alſo the Gentiles perceaued: which affirmed, that it was the best thing not to be borne, or being once borne, ſhortly to die. Therefore this place is to be vnderſtāded plainly by way of compariſon.

div.head: Alſo I beheld all trauayle and perfectiō of workes, that is in the enuie of a mā againſt his neighbour: This alſo is a vanitie and vexation of the mynde.
div.p: An other kynde of mans miſery, enuie, hatred, cō tention, vſed in this lyfe.HEre is another kynde of calamitie & impediment of mans deuiſes: Euen as among great men, and men of power raigne ſclaundering and oppreſſing. &c. So among the commōs is there nothing but enuy, emulation and hatred. &c.

Looke vpon the comminaltie, and conſider the artificers, there thou ſhalt finde how euill diſpoſed they are, what naughtines,
fraude, deceite, and backbiting is among them, and how they hate, and enuye one another to the death. If a man be cunning in any thing he is hated, and hath enemies. He that is a good workemā hath an hundred that hate hym: whereby it commeth to paſſe as the Poet ſaith, that the potter enuieth the potter, the Smith, the Smith, and the Poet the Poet. This is the caſe and courſe of all Artificers. Imagine there were one that woulde learne ſome craft or occupation,Men muſt not leaue their vocatiō becauſe of the euill will, or vnthākfulnes of others. wherby to get his liuing in tyme to come. If he ſhould learne it ſo exactely that he ſhould paſſe other therein, then would other a great many enuy and hate hym. What then: Shoulde he leaue of? Shoulde he learne nothing? No. But labour ſtyll to his power, and commit his worke vnto God. What ſhall we doe at our ſtudye and bookes? Shall we geue ouer, becauſe our Schollers perceaue not this, or that thyng? or becauſe learned men are deſpiſed? No: goe forward with that thou haſt in hand. Waite ſtill for the houre. For thou knoweſt it is well done to teach other. Regarde not therfore the worlde, or thine owne deuiſes: Whereto ſoeuer
thou applieſt thy ſelfe, thou ſhalt finde troubles.

We muſt follow our vocatiō although mē enuye, or hate vs.We thought in theſe dayes, to haue done many good by meanes of the Goſpell, and hoped that all men would haue embraced it, but euen they whom wée benefited, in deliuering them from the Popes tyranny, doe foulely bewray vs, and they at whoſe handes we looked for ayde and helpe, treade vs vnder theyr feete. What ſhall we now doe? Shal we take indignation thereat? Shal we ceaſe of from all our doing? No. Let them enuie, deſpiſe and perſecute: we will holde on as long as we are able, teaching, labouring, writing, learning, for ſo is gods will we ſhould. For without enuye, no man that meaneth well to doe, ſhal lyue in this world. We muſt not appoint the tyme when our trauell ſhall doe good. Let God alone therewith. Onely, ſée thou labour, and doe that God appoynteth thée. And thinke not that thou art able to redreſſe all thynges, to ſée that all Officers be good, and all Artificers and craftes men at peace and vnitie. Thus therefore he ſayth:

div.head:
I ſaw the induſtrie and perfection
that is in workemen.
div.p: THat is,Warninges and comforted Euangelicall. I ſawe men well framed & diſpoſed to their duties and occupations, but they coulde bring nothing to paſſe according to their deſires, becauſe it was not in their power, the hatred of their neighbours was ſuch an hindrance to them. Therfore theſe be playnely admonitions and comfortes of the Goſpell, which call vs frō the eares of this world. For many are the heapes of mans vanitie and miſerie, and euery where at hand. When I firſt began to preach, I trauelled diligently to make all mē good, but it was ſayd to me, and that truely: he is to yong as yet to teach olde knaues to become honeſt men.

The ſame falleth out in all other profeſſions. This euill beſtyrreth it ſelfe in euery kinde of lyfe. The beſt is therfore to enioy the thinges we haue, and to goe forward with that we haue in hand, and to let euill paſſe by vs. And ſo ſhall we delude the worlde.

To be ſhort, he that will liue quietly,How a mā may lyue. muſt thinke with himſelfe, that he ſhall ſée nothing in the world but vanitie, and thē ſhal it not greue him, if any euil happen,
& he ſhall reioyce in thoſe goods that God hath geuē him. And if yu be driuen to ſuch neceſſitie yt thou art cōpelled to prouide for thy ſelfe, doe that is lawfull for thée, and then let God doe what pleaſeth him. But if thou wilt wittingly geue thy ſelfe vnto the worlde,All things can not be redreſſed. to correcte all that is amiſſe, and to remedy all incōuiences, and wilt driue Satan out of the worlde: thou ſhalt procure thy ſelfe trauell and ſorrow, and nought els, and ſhalt as little preuaile, as if thou wouldeſt goe about to ſtoppe the courſe of the riuer Albis from flowing. The affayres of thys world will not nor can not be gouerned at mās pleaſure, but he yt made them all, the ſame ruleth thē alſo as he ſéeth good.

div.head: This alſo is a vanitie and vexation of ſpirite.
div.p:
IF for example thou wouldeſt remedye this enuie, and ſuch like euils. Let them enuie one another, lette and hynder one another, deale vniuſtly one with another: if God meane to vſe thy helpe and counſell, he will doe it in his tyme and place: waite thou for that. Euen ſo now, if it pleaſe him to preſerue ſtudies and ſchooles, he knoweth the tyme and perſons
by whom to doe it. They whome we thinke fitte for this purpoſe, be many tymes moſt vnhandſome and vnfitte.

div.head: The foole foldeth his handes, and eateth vp his owne fleſhe.
div.p:
A Foole in this place ſignifieth not (as we commonly vnderſtand it) a dyſſarde or natural,Whom Salomon calleth fooles. but a wicked man and a naughty, whom in the Dutch toung we call, a lewde vngodly perſon: ſuch as are thoſe enuious bodyes, who beyng not able to doe any thing themſelues, doe yet diſturbe and hinder other. Such men being of no accompt themſelues, and without wit and induſtrie, doe no good whyle they liue, but be greeuous vnto others. Euen like thoſe yt teach or learne naughtely, fooliſhe and vnlearned preachers: ſo are there among artificers, ſuch drones, as we call pelters or counterfectours, which onely be impedimentes to other, and can doe no good them ſelues. Such there are among the magiſtrates, hynderers of the common weale, ſo that they moſt diſturbe the common weale, good ſtudies, and other vertuouſnes, who we hoped woulde moſt haue furthered the
ſame. So many fooliſhe preachers more hynder the Goſpell, then the profeſſed enemies of the ſame.

div.head: ¶The foole therefore foldeth hys handes.
div.p: HE is no earneſt labourer, no wakefull perſon, but a ſluggard and ſleper, which careth not for his labour, but hindreth contemneth, and backbiteth other. This is to fold the hands: to doe nought him ſelfe, but to hinder and let other. The like phraſe is in the vj. of the Prouerbes. Fold thy handes, and pouertie ſhall come on thee as one that trauelleth by the waye. To folde the handes together, a ſigne of ſome euill lucke. Hereof it ſéemeth to come that Pliny ſaith: It bodeth ſome euill lucke to fold the handes together, which was very well ſayd of them but not vnderſtanded. Contrarywiſe of a diligent and good houſewife it is ſayd: Her handes layd hold on the ſpyndle, that is, She doth earneſtly meane it. Such fooliſh and naughty men doth God raiſe vp to hinder and let our deuiſes.

div.head: He eateth his owne fleſh.
div.p:
AGaine this is an Hebrew phraſe, for he conſumeth him ſelfe. The like is
in Hiob. To eate ones owne fleſh, is to vexe hym ſelfe. I teare my fleſhe with my teeth. This he meaneth. Such fooliſhe men profite not them ſelues, but hurt & withſtand other men. He enuyeth at other men, and fretteth him ſelfe awaye. Such a man in a common weale is lyke vnto ruſt and wormes, hurtfull both to him ſelfe and to other. And therefore do they likewiſe continue as patches.

div.head: ¶Better is one handful with quietnes, then two handes full with labour and vexation of mynde.
div.p:
THis may be vnderſtode to be ſpoken either of the foole by way of imitation,Men muſt be content wt meane eſtate. or els plainely and by way of affirmatiō of Salomon. If by way of imitation thē muſt it be taken as a wiſe counſell of a fooliſh man, which abuſeth a very good ſaying, after his doltiſh ſorte, as ſuch as he is vſed to doe. As if he ſhould ſay: why ſhould I take ſuch paynes, as doth this mā, wearyeng and toyling him ſelfe with ſuch labour and trauell? Why ſhould I weare my ſelfe away? I ſhal receaue aſmuch as an other, ſo excuſing his ſlouthfulnes, as a certeine Monke ſayd, affirming there was no reaſon why he
ſhould conſume him ſelfe awaye by ſtudying, conſidering he receaued as large a portion as the Doctour. Amongeſt ſuch felowes we haue to liue, although they be intollerable euen as when we are cō ſtrayned to walke thorough woodes and thickettes, where we muſt ſtriue to get out, although the brambles and thornes ſtay and hinder vs neuer ſo much. For this worlde is nothyng but thornes. If thou wilt take them affirmatiuely as the wordes & counſel of Salomon, which ſence pleaſeth me beſt, then this is the meaning. Seyng in all affaires there be lettes & impedimentes, what ſhal a man doe? Freat not thy ſelfe, though ſuch fooles hinder thée. And if the foole will fret him ſelfe, yet hold thou on in thy labour, and enioye that thou haſt gotten mearily. If thou cāſt not haue both thine handes full, take in good part that God giueth thée, though it be but an handfull. And although thy gaine be but ſmall, yet content thy ſelfe, and liue chearefully therewith.

div.head:
I turned my ſelfe, and ſaw an other vanitie vnder the Sunne. There is one alone, and not a ſecond, which
hath neither ſonne nor brother: yet is there no ende of his trauell, neyther can his eyes bee ſatiſfied with riches, nether doth he thinke, for whom doe I trauell, & defraude my ſelfe of pleaſure? This alſo is vanitie, and an euill trauell.
div.p: SAlomon goeth on,The couetous are reprooued. in reckonyng the cares that follow the vanities of men, among the which he accompteth this couetous Euclio, which gathereth & hourdeth vp heapes, and yet can enioy none. All the worlde for the moſt part is entāgled with this vice. All men ſéeke that is their owne, and prouide for the belly, yet chiefely he reprehendeth ſuch as breake their braynes to enriche themſelues, and onely gather for others, neither abydyng a tyme to get them, neither to enioy thē.

div.head: There is one alone. &c.
div.p:
THis vice the Poets alſo condenme, and worthely deride in their fables. For the couetous man enioyeth not hys golde, he onely looketh on it, and yet his eyes are not ſatiſfied, euen as the Poets fayne of Tantalus. For thus wryteth Horace:
The thirstie Tantalus doth ſtande, in water vp to chinne:
And faine woulde of the Riuer drinke, that glydeth by full thynne.
Laugh not (I ſay) for chaunge the name, and then the tale is tolde:
Of thee that heapſt and ſleepſt vppon, thy bagges of gathered golde.
Or as a man that feares to touch, ſome holy thyng, art fayne,
To looke and gape vppon thy golde, or els from it refraine.

div.head: It is better therefore there be two then one, for of their labour commeth ſome profite. For if one fall, his fellow will lift him vp. Wo vnto him that is alone. For when he falleth there is none to lift hym vp. And whē two ſleepe together, they ſhall one warme an other. But how ſhal one becom whot. And though one may ouercome one, yet two may make reſiſtaunce: a threefolde corde is not eaſely broken.
div.p:
THis is the counſel of Salomon commendyng ſocietie and fellowſhyp of goodes, and commaundyng vs to vſe
things preſent,A commē dation of cōmunitie of goodes, for goodnes will communicate it ſelfe. and not to labour for our ſelues onely, but for others behoofe alſo. Fellowſhyp is profitable for the preſeruatiō of goodes. The couetous body will haue no partener or fellow and condemneth the communitie of goods gathering to him ſelfe onely, beyng a very dogge at the hey ſtacke. Theſe ſolitary perſons, and ſcrapers, no men but beaſtes, Salomon in this place condemneth. It is better ſaith he to liue in ſocietie and fellowſhip of goodes, for if one fall. &c.

This place they racked to ſinne and confeſſion,The deprauyng of this place. thus vnderſtanding and expounding this text. If any mā had fallen in ſinne, and had had no holy mā to haue made his confeſſion to, he had not béene able to haue riſen into the way of grace and godlines. Howbeit we haue declared that Salomon ſpeaketh of the courſe of mans life vnder the ſunne, agaynſt mās vayne vexing of him ſelfe. For he commendeth the ſocietie and fellowſhyp of mā in enioyeng their goodes, agaynſt the ſolitary life of the couetous. This is that he ſayth. The couetous mā profiteth neither him ſelfe, nor other. No man féeleth any commoditie by him, as he that liueth
not with any man, but kéepeth his goodes onely to him ſelfe, yea in hauyng them, hath them not. But who ſo leadeth not his life in ſuch ſolitary wiſe, of him commeth ſome commoditie, beyng profitable to him ſelfe, and receauing cō moditie of others. For this ſocietie maketh to the preſeruyng and encreaſing of goodes. This is it, that he afterward addeth: hee hath none to helpe him. Agayne: how ſhall one become warme? He hath no helpe, no counſell, no comfort in affliction. What hath he when he alone gathereth for him ſelfe? he is onely a beholder of his money, as it were of ſome painted table.

div.head: ¶ A threefolde corde is not eaſely broken.
div.p:
Cōmunion of benefites is a band of humane cōſolation.HE entermedleth a feate Prouerbe, as he doth oftentimes hereafter, and that according to the manner of a good preacher. The meaning is, It is better to haue fellowes, and to enioye thinges in commune, then to be a couetous body, ſolitary, rapyng and reuyng onely for him ſelfe. In fellowſhip there is mutual helpe, ayde and comforte, where the couetous
mans life is miſerable, vayne & full of affliction, beyng at length compelled to dye like a miſer. This thing he cō firmeth by a Prouerbe, borowed as it may ſeeme hereof. A certaine wiſe father ready to depart this worlde, called hys ſonnes vnto hym, deliueryng them a bundle of roddes to breake, which when they could not breake, beyng bounde faſt together, yet being taken in ſunder, they brake. Therby teaching his ſonnes, that their force and power ſhould be inuincible as long as they liued in vnitie together, and would one helpe an other. For thorough concorde ſmall thinges would grow & encreaſe, where through diſcorde they would loſe and fall in ſunder.

div.head: Better is a poore and wiſe childe, thē an old and fooliſh kyng, which will no more be admoniſhed.
div.p:
HEre is an other kynde of lyfe after theſe couetous perſons and vnprofitable to others.He reprehendeth ambition. Euen as he ſayd there was vanitie in couetouſnes, ſo now he ſaith there is the ſame in ambition. For many are borne to be kinges, and yet remaine not ſo. Many come out of the priſon
and become kinges and richmen. Other forgoe their kingdomes and become ſeruaunts, becauſe we ſhould know, that our deuiſes are nothing. Our counſell, our endeuour doth nothyng. Therefore ſome of captiues become kinges, and gouerne well, becauſe God proſpereth thē, and ſome that be borne kynges gouerne naughtely. I haue ſéene many children godlyly brought vp, and very well inſtructed, whiche when their tutor hath béene gone, and they come to their inheritaunce, haue prooued very vngracious and wicked graftes. And other without any education and inſtructiō haue made good men, what then? Shall we neglect our childrē? Shall we not inſtruct them? Shall we ſet all at ſix and ſeuen? No.

Labour is cōmaunded but care forbidden.This booke ſéemeth vtterly to teach vs negligence & ſlacknes in thynges, but it doth nothyng leſſe. It teacheth vs in déede to ſet naught by our owne deuiſes, and cares, wherewith we trouble & vexe our minde. So while the Goſpell reiecteth the righteouſnes of workes, it ſetteth not our hand at liberty, but our conſcience, becauſe God hath commaunded the worke, but forbiddē the care. So our
children muſt be inſtructed, but touching their profite therein the care muſt be cō mitted to God. Euen as the huſbandmā muſt ſow his ſéede, but commit the care of his crop vnto God. Euen as God by his law that he gaue this people, omitted nothing that might belong to the gouerning of them, although it tooke not ſuch effect as it ought, and fell out euill wt a great many: ſo muſt the Magiſtrate haue a diligēt care, that the cōmon weale may be well gouerned, and defended, but yet not truſt to his owne induſtrie and counſell. He muſt do his diligence and take paynes &c. But he muſt put away cares and vexation of mynde. For we muſt not preſcribe God any meanes, place, or tyme. As the huſbandman throweth his ſéede into the grounde, afterwarde he goeth his way, and taketh hys reſt, nothing carefull for the encreaſe, for els he ſhould neuer haue any reſt. Therfore let no man thinke that Salomon cō dēneth mēs labour. He forbiddeth cares & anxieties, but labour he requireth.

div.head: For out of the priſon he commeth forth to reigne, where he that is borne a kyng loſeth the ſame.
div.p: The affayres of man paſſe wōderfully and are not ruled by our deuiſes.THis ſaying agréeth with the premiſſes in this wyſe: therfore is a wyſe childe better then an olde foole, becauſe many tymes it cōmeth to paſſe, that ſome commeth out of the priſon to a kingdome, & ſome other of kings fal to be ignominius and fooliſh, as Manaſſe, Zedechias. But contrariwyſe Ioſeph being deliuered out of priſon, became ye chief ruler in Aegipt. And in our dayes Matthias kyng of Hū gary being brought out of the priſon was made a mighty kyng. Such thynges many tymes come to paſſe in the world, as the Romaine hiſtories declare. Valerianus none of the worſt Emperours, being taken priſoner, ſerued for a ſtoole to the kyng of Perſia to get on horſebacke by all the dayes of his life. How happened it ſo vnto him? Becauſe his houre appointed of God was come. Wherfore then take we ſuch cares: Sufficient to the day, is the care and trauel therof.

The education of a kyng.Therefore a kynges ſonne muſt be enfourmed, and brought vp like a kyng, but to preſcribe him what he ſhall doe in tyme to come, and how good a kyng he ſhall be, is but an afflicting of the minde. This muſt be committed vnto the determination
and will of God, and we muſt ſay: Lord God I enſtruct and teach thys childe in déede, but make thou hym a kyng, at thy will and pleaſure.

div.head: I beheld all the lyuing which walke vnder the Sunne, with the ſeconde childe, which ſhall ſtand vp in hys place. There is none ende of all the people, and of all that were before them, & they that come after ſhall ſhall not reioyce in hym. This is alſo vanitie and vexation of ſpirit.
div.p:
SAlomon calleth the lyuing, thoſe that lyue gorgiouſly, and as though they ſought for no other lyfe, but that ye world had béene created for their ſake onely, as the Gallaunts of the court vſe to doe. He cōtinueth in the example of a kings education, whether it be to gouerne at home, or in the fielde. Education (ſayth he) is a good thing, but mans will & ſtudie bringeth not to paſſe that he would. The deuiſes of education are deceitfull, the trauell is neceſſary, but the ſucceſſe and care oftentimes beguileth vs.Our deuiſes deceaue vs. Therfore he teacheth vs that our deuiſes are vayne. For if care and counſell deceaue vs in a kings
