education, how much more wyll it deceaue in education of the cōmons, where is leſſe care, and ſlenderer education.

That he ſayth the liuing, or all ye ſtates vnder the Sunne, kéepe company wyth the ſecond childe, he meaneth not all ſimply, but the moſt part of the kingdome: ſo that the ſence is, all the company that be about the kyng, waite and attende vppon the kinges ſonne his becke. Euery one cleaueth vnto him, hauing cōceaued ſome great hope of him. For this younge Prince is the ſecond youth or ſpringall, which ſtandeth in ſtéede of another king, that is, which ſhall be kyng, and ſucceede in the kyngdome after his Father: Before whome, and behinde whom is there a great company of people, that is to ſay, he is waited on with a great multitude of people behinde & before, garding him, as though he were kyng. There is a great hope in this young man, that he ſhould paſſe his father in power and authoritie. All mē déemed and iudged very well of him, and yet they reioyced not in him. Why ſo? Becauſe he aunſwered not their expectation, becauſe he prooued ſuch a foole and dullard, accordyng to the prouerbe,
ſaying: eyther a king, or a foole borne.

Thus Nero in great hope and ioye of the people was made kyng,Nero. in ſo much as the firſt fiue yeares of his raigne is of great fame and renowne. But the yeares after prooued moſt vnlyke.Heliogabalus. Cōmodus. So Heliogabalus and Commodus alſo were choſē Princes and Emperours, wyth great expectation of the people that they woulde be good men, but they deceaued all men of their hope and looking. For one of thē degenerated into a moſt filthy man, yea into a beaſt, rather then a man: the other fell out to be moſt incommodious, and ye third prooued Nero. Good princes are rare & ſeldeom. Wherefore a good Prince is a moſt rare Phoenix. For mēs counſels are deceaueable, in ſo much that he of whom we conceaued many tymes ſome ſingular hope, him we moſt repent vs of. So Roboam, Roboam did degenerate. the ſonne of a moſt wiſe father, of whom ſurely ye people cō ceaued a very good hope, as one brought vp godlyly vnder his father: yet prooued he moſt vnlike to his father. If therfore mens counſels ſo faile in the hyeſt degrée of lyfe, they will much more fayle in the life of priuate perſons, in thy houſe, in thine office &c. For euen there alſo thou
ſhalt haue thy childe eyther an artificer, and workeman, or a foole. &c.

In déede he ſpeaketh of kynges, for in honorable perſonages are honorable exploytes and déedes, that is, ſuch as are apparaunt. The déedes of priuate perſōs commonly are eyther neglected, or leſſe obſerued and marked: but according to the Duch prouerbe, A wiſe man committeth no ſmall follie. If a Commonner offende, or committe ſome fooliſhe facte, it is not much regarded. Otherwiſe, ye ſtate and condition of priuate men and kings is all like.

Labour & endeuour are not condemned, but mens owne deuiſe and carefulnes.Therfore Salomon condemneth not the paines taken in education of a kyng, in enriching of a childe, in gouerning of a familie and houſholde, but our deuiſes, whereby we will rule and order all the matter. He commaūdeth the worke, but he forbiddeth thée the care. Trauell thou inſtantly, but committe the ſucceſſe and effecte to God. Remember the example of the king diligently brought vp and enfourmed, & yet altered, that thou mayſt know how thynges goe not by our deuiſes and endeuours, but by the will of God, which hath appointed a tyme and
ſeaſon for euery thing, out of the which nothing can at any tyme ſucceede. Therfore if he aunſwere to his education, thankes muſt be geuen vnto God, not to our ſtudie and care, but vnto Gods bleſſing. If our corne grow well, we haue to thanke God for it, not our ſelues. For how is man able to defende his corne eyther from byrdes, or beaſtes, or wormes, or from the enuy of Satan. Therefore it lyeth not in our care and carke, but in the fauour and bleſſing of God, to the ende we ſhould thanke him onely, which worketh all in all, according to his good will and pleaſure. So falleth it out in the education of our children. If thou haſt a good childe, ſay the Lord hath geuen him and brought it ſo to paſſe: If not, ſay, this is the proofe and ſtate of mans life, I did my diligēce, the Lord would not haue it ſo: hys name be bleſſed.

div.head: The fifth Chapter.

Take heede to thy foote, whē thou entreſt into the houſe of God, and draw nere to heare: for that is better then the Sacrifices of fooles,
for they know not how much hurt they doe.
div.p:
The abuſe of this booke. HEre doe I beginne the fifth Chapiter, for it is a new place. By reading this booke, it happeneth to the vnwiſe, as vnto the vngodly, through the preaching of the Goſpell. For when theſe men heare the righteouſnes of fayth and Chriſtian libertie preached, and the righteouſnes of workes denyed, by and by they reply: let vs then doe no workes, but let vs ſinne on ſtill, for faith is ſufficient. Contrariwyſe, if workes be preached as fruits of fayth, ſtraightway they attribute iuſtification to them, & ſéeke ſaluation in them. So alway theſe two thinges follow the worde of God, preſumption and deſperation, ſo that it is an hard matter to holde the right way. The lyke falleth out by this booke. The vnwyſe when they heare this doctrine, that we ought to be quyet in hart and mynde, and to committe all vnto God, inferre thus: If all thinges be in Gods hand and power, then will we not labour at all. Euen as the other offende on the other ſide, in being too carefull,
while they will moderate and rule all things after their owne meaſure & deuiſe. But we muſt all holde the ſtrayght way to doe our diligence, and what we are able, according to the worde of God, but not to meaſure our doinges after our owne deuiſe, but to commit all the ſucceſſe of our doinges to Gods wiſdome.

It ſeemeth to me therefore, that Salomon in this place vſeth a kynde of preuention, and wholeſome exhortation to them that walke not in the right way, but either are too remiſſe & ſlacke of theyr labour, or els too carefull, counſelling them to be ruled by the worde of God, and yet in ye meane ſeaſon to take paines and doe their endeuour diligently.

div.head: Take heede to thy foote, whē thou entreſt into the houſe of God.
div.p:
THe temple or houſe of God was ordeined not ſo much for ſacrificyng,Why churches and aſſemblies of people were inſtituted. as for preachyng, that the people of God might méete together, to heare the word of God. As a Prince calleth his houſe together, not onely to eate and drinke, but to heare his word &c. Therefore where the word of God is not heard there is no
aſſembly of Gods people or houſe.Why he biddeth thē to looke to their feete. He commaūdeth them to take héede to their féete rather then their hart, to the ende, they ſhould not be offended when they heare this doctrine, as Dauid ſaith in the Pſalme: My feete were almoſt gone. For after the worde of God, whether it treate of peace of conſcience, or outward peace, followeth offence. For it is that ſigne that ſhall be ſpoken againſt, for the fall and riſing agayne of many. Euen as Chriſt ſaith: Bleſſed is hee whiche is not offended at me. To be ſhort, the word of God is offence and fooliſhnes to the fleſh.Our doings & deuiſes muſt be ruled by the word of God. Thus he ſaith therfore: Thou heareſt when I teach thée, but take héede thou be not offended, or make my teachyng a ſtumblyng blocke to thée: that when thou heareſt, a man ſhould quyet his mynde, and that his deuiſes be in vayne, thou ſay not, then will not I labour at all, or thinke then thou haſt nothing to doe. Or contrarywiſe, that thou be not ouer carefull, and wouldeſt gouerne and rule all thyng after thine own reaſon. Mans cares, diſputations, and counſels, are as vneffectual as Plato his policie or common weale. But if thou
wilt auoyde all offences, geue thy ſelfe to the word of God, and to his workyng, and caſt thyne owne deuiſes and cogitations away. Open thine eares and bee perſuaded. Draw neare to harken. For in no wayes neither of Gods nor mans can we be in ſafetie, onles we giue ouer our ſelues wholly to the word and workyng of God, and ſtay vs therupon without any waueryng of mynde.

div.head: For this is better then the ſacrifices of fooles.
div.p:
THis is added by way of a Prouerbe,To harken to ye worde of God, is better then the ſacrifices of fooles. to confirme this ſentence. It is better to harken to ye worde of God, then all the ſacrifices and worſhippings of fooles. This he ſaith, becauſe he would extoll hearing and obeyeng of the word, aboue all workes. For it is méeteſt of all, that we ſhould harken to the counſell of our God, as often as we come into the houſe of God. The wicked tyre and werye thē ſelues in their workes, forſakyng the counſell of God.Who be fooles. And here mayſt thou ſée what a foole ſignifieth with ye Hebrewes, not him that we call a dyſarde, but him that harkeneth not to the worde of God,
or beleueth it not with his hart, although otherwiſe he be neuer ſo prudēt, becauſe ſuch men know not God, neither the thinges belongyng to God, much leſſe care they for them, but are vexed and caryed about with cares, caryng for that is not worthy to be cared for. Their care is how to doe ſacrifice. But lay thou holde on the beſt part: harken to the worde of God, and beware thou be not offended at it.

div.head: For they know not how much hurt they doe.
div.p:
Hypocrites know not how much hurte they doe.BY theſe wordes he expoundeth what fooles are. For ſurely there is no mā ſo euill, which would commit euill, if he knew it were euill in Gods ſight. Therfore he calleth thoſe fooles, ignorauntes, and blinde, which doe many thynges as though they were good, and with great earneſtnes, but yet are ignoraunt that theſe ſacrifices which they ſo buſily make are vtterly impious. Thus Chriſt calleth the Phariſeis blinde, which vſed to offer many ſacrifices, and to weary them ſelues in workes, but neglected faith and charitie, yea knew them not, calling that
good that was euill, and ſo contraryly. Truly therfore doth Salomon call them fooles.

Here thou ſéeſt that the higheſt,The fooliſhenes of hypocrites. and chiefeſt pointe in religion is called, euill. For he ſpeaketh of ſacrifice whiche they made with great good intent and earneſtnes, becauſe they did it, and regarded not the word of God. Abyde therfore in the worde, leaſt thou neglect the ſame, and follow thine owne wayes, and fall into ye ſacrifices of fooles, as they did which vowed chaſtitie, pouertie, obedience, and ſuch lyke, neglecting the worde of God. All theſe in this doing were offended, and their féete ſlipped.

div.head: Be not raſhe with thy mouth, nor let thyne hart be haſtye, to vtter a thing before God: for God is in heauen, and thou art on the earth. Therefore let thy wordes be fewe, for many cares breede dreames, and multitude of wordes declareth a foole.
div.p:
THis is one parte of them which are offēded, and decline to ye right hand,He warneth vs to auoyde offences. which to much weary them ſelues and
reaſon of goddes counſelles. Euen as other ſay, if we ſhould doo nothing but only beleue, then let vs doo no workes: ſo theſe men ſay, if our counſelles be of no force, then what ſhall we doo? wherfore did God make vs on this wiſe? wherfore geueth he one man good ſucceſſe, and another none? Salomon therefore counſelleth vs in this place not to yelde to ſuch cogitations, or to follow ſuch diſputers, but to abyde in the woorde, and to doo yt God preſcribeth vs. Neither to regarde the ones ouermuch carefulnes, nor the others ouer greate negligēce, but to hold on in the ſtraight and high waye.

div.head: Before God.
div.p:
THat is, in the houſe of God, in this place where God is woorſhipped & preached, there be not to haſty to ſpeak, that is, become not a teacher, but ſuffer thy ſelfe to be taught. The wicked after they haue heard the woorde, doo by & by barke and murmure at it, ſome on the left hand, other ſome on the right, both of thē being ſwift to ſpeake before God, while they will place their doctrines in
ſteede of Gods. Therfore follow not y• neither thine owne, nor their woordes, but harkē what ye Lord ſayth, as Iames teacheth thee: Be not many maiſters. The meaning is,The onely ſonne of God is to be followed as our teacher, & nothing muſt be taught contrary to Gods worde. be not a maſter of thy ſelfe, or of other, neyther harken to thy ſelfe, or to other, but onely to the woord of God. For one is your Maiſter and teacher which is Chriſt, who is in heauen, heare him.

div.head: Dreaming commeth through multitude of cares.
div.p:
THeſe be two prouerbes which he applyeth to his ſaying:Oſtentatiō of wiſdome & ouermuch that reprehended. for it cometh to paſſe that where many cares and cogitations go before in the daye, that dyuers dreames follow in the night, euen by the iudgement of the Phiſitions. This generall prouerbe, thus he applyeth: If thou reaſon & be carefully buſied in thy minde how to order thinges, and wilt take care for all matters, there will enſue nothing but dreames, which will delude thee when thou art waked, that is at length thou ſhalt conclude but vayne matters. 1. Timoth. Knowing not what they
ſay, nor whereof they affirme. So where we & others appoint many ways, yet none of thē is followed, much more when we preferre our cogitations and counſelles before the word of God.

div.head: And multitude of wordes bewrayeth a foole.
div.p:
THat is to diſpute of dyuers matters, to be to wiſe in our owne opinions, to teach and preſcribe all men argueth a foole. Therby is a foole to be knowen when he will ſeeme to be wiſe. Ouerhaſty wyſedome and righteouſnes commeth neuer to perfection as one ſayd: I hate that boy that is wiſe to ſoone. This therfore is his counſell, that we ſhould not be ſo ready to diſpute and reaſon, as to harken and doo. And this text might haue bene cōcluded in two words: Heare, and holde thy peace. For he that can geue good eare, we ſay in our Dutch prouerbe he will be a wiſe man. And he that with many wordes & much diſputing, wil ſéeme to redreſſe matters, is a foole, and ſetteth thinges the more backeward. Theſe are therefore notable prouerbes, for manners, and which may
be ſpoken agaynſt thoſe, which through their owne deuiſes will get their lyuing or which through their workes will preſcribe God a rule &c. Euen as Iudas calleth them dreamers, which will order & appoint the Church without the worde of God.

div.head: For God is in heauen, but thou art on the earth.
div.p:
THat is remember thy ſtate or condition.God muſt be heard & obeyed. The greate maieſtie of God is in heauen, thou art but a worme on the earth. Thou muſt not talke of Goddes workes after thine owne iudgement, let God rather ſpeake: diſpute not of Gods Counſelles, nor goe not about to bringe thine own matters to paſſe through thine owne counſels. It is God alone that can diſpoſe, and bring all matters to paſſe, for he is in heauen. All this we thus expreſſe in the Germaine toung: fewe wordes, holde thy toung. Thou ſhalt appoint God no rule. Theſe men therfore offend on the left hand, which will not heare the word of God, but they will helpe matters to goe forward, and teach God what he hath to doe. Theſe men he thus beateth
downe: Heare, and holde your peace, and doe that which God commaundeth & appointeth you, which if you will not doe, you ſhall offende, and ſo become a dreamer and a foole.

div.head: When thou haſt vowed a vowe vnto God, differre not to pay it, for he delighteth not in fooles. Paye therfore that thou haſt vowed. It is better that thou voweſt not, thē to vow, and not perfourme.
div.p:
The doctrine of vowing.THis place is greatly toſſed in the Church and kyngdome of the Pope, as the onely foundation whereon they buylde and ſet vp their Monkiſh vowes. We diſpute not whether vowes are to be perfourmed or not, but whether the vowes which they vaunte of, be vowes, yea,What things may be vowed. or no. Hierome and Lyra agrée both in this, that a vow ought to be ſuch as is poſſible for vs to perfourme, and concerneth the glory of God. This they call a fooliſhe vowe, to gather vp ſtrawes from the grounde, and to claw the head wyth one finger. And Moſes reciteth diuers kyndes of vowes, and what thyngs may be vowed, namely a fielde, an houſe,
meate, cloth, our owne bodye, all which are in our power. Thus the Iewes vowed their lyfe and body to the Prieſtes, to ſerue them for a certain time appointed. Furthermore,The vowes of the olde teſtament. Moſes hath no perpetuall vowe, but one which he calleth Anathema, namely a vowe of death, in ye laſt of Leuit. that that muſt be ſlayne whether it were man or beaſt that was vowed, as did Iepthe in the eleuenth of Iudges.

Wherfore if Monkes will bragge of their perpetuall vowes,The vowes of Monkes. they muſt by & by be killed, if they will defende theyr vowes by Moſes authoritie. Otherwyſe all vowes be poſſible, and for a tyme, ſo that thou mayſt vow thy bodye to God, alſo thy fielde, thy medow, thy garment, for a certain tyme. &c. that the Leuite, or Prieſt may haue the vſe of it. This kinde of vow was very profitable for ye Leuits, for their better maintenaunce & finding. And God appointed this for their prouiſion. Our vowes are vtterly fooliſhe,What our vowes and wiſhes be. if (I ſay) not impious. For we vow poueruertie and obedience, which are cōmaunded in the Goſpell to all Chriſtians.To vowe virginitie is a thyng impoſſible. To vow virginitie is impoſſible, Ergo, by Hierome and Lyra his iudgement, they
are no vowes. Howbeit this place of Salomon ſéemeth to me, to pertain to thoſe that are on the right hand, who hearyng that their owne wayes profit them not, will afterward doe nothing at all. For thus the foole diſputeth: if by mine owne care and deuiſe, I can not bryng that I will to paſſe, then will I not perfourme that I haue vowed. &c. Againſt theſe contemners he ſayth: Doe that that God commaundeth: I quit thée not from labouring, but I appoint thée to doe that ye God hath commaunded. He commaundeth thée to pay or perfourme that thou haſt vowed. Conclude all theſe ſayinges thus: Harken, holde thy peace, and doe that thou haſt to doe, that is, that God commaundeth thee.

div.head: For he is not delighted in fooles.
div.p:
God is angry wyth ſcorners & cōtemners.NOw confirmeth he his ſaying with a threatening from God, he ſpeaketh of ſuch fooles (after the manner of Scripture) as contemne and regarde not the worde of God: Be not reachles, make not light of it, for you ſhall not eſcape vnpuniſhed, but abyde ſuch payne as is ordained for them whom God forſaketh,
and is angry with.

div.head: Suffer not thy mouth to make thy fleſhe to ſinne, neyther ſay before the Angel, that this is ignoraunce, leaſt god be angry with thy ſaying, and deſtroy the woorkes of thyne handes. Many wordes are but dreames, and vanities, but feare thou the Lord.
div.p:
THis is a confirmation of the ſame ſē tence,Contempte of God cō demned. admoniſhing vs that we be not obſtinate in refuſing to doe yt we ought, as he taught vs before, not to be too carefull, & to doe all according to our phāſie; & deuiſe. Speake not (ſayth he) ſo carnally, ſo raſhely, ſo fooliſhely, to harken to thyne owne fleſhe, but ſpeake accordyng to the wrode of God. And ſay not this is ignoraunce, or a trifling fault, if I labour not, or perfourme not that I haue promiſed, as men of light conſciences make light of ſinne, and thinke that God regardeth not ſinnes, or requireth not our good deedes. See thou excuſe thee not, or neglecte if thou offēde him. For hereof ſpring hereſies, when they ſet the word of God at naught, and ſhamefully defende it,
ſtanding ſo highly in their owne conceit, that they thinke they haue no neede of Gods worde.

What the Hebrew worde Sigaion ſignifieth.This ſecuritie or negligence, the Hebrew word Sigaion declareth, which is vſed alſo in the title of the ſeuenth Pſal. & in the title of ye ſong of Habacuc. For it ſignifieth ignoraunce, but not that that we call fooliſhnes or lacke of knowledge, but rather that which more truely we may call lacke of conſcience, or inconſcience, if that were a Latine word, that is, when one doth not know a thing, or maketh no conſcience of it: ſo that yu mayſt referre it not to the Angell, but vnto him that ſaith: I know no fault by my ſelfe, God will not reprooue me.

div.head: Before the Angell.
div.p:
BEcauſe God gouerned this people by the meane of Angels as is ſayde in the epiſtle to ye Galathyans. The law was ordayned by Angels, in the hand of a mediatour. And Moyſes ſayth: to the people. The Angell ſhall go before you, commending to them the Angell yt gouerned them: after this maner Salomon ſayth: ſay not before the angell.
&c. whom the Lord hath appoynted to be our gouernour Before the Angell is all one, as if he ſhould ſay, before God: Leaſt God be angry with the ſame. &c. that is: See thou contemne not thy vow & ſo become infortunate in all thy waies and doinges.

Afterward he cōcludeth all this place,Where many cares be, there are many dreames & vanities. after ye ſame ſort, & with ye ſame ſentēce almoſt that went before: Dreames only & vanities &c. For where many cares are, there be many dreames, and where are many counſels, and diſputations, there be many vanities. Therefore feare thou God, be content with his worde, & ſuffer him to rule at his pleaſure. For he is in heauen, and thou on the earth, as afore is ſayd. Labour thou, but let hym gouerne thy labour & geue ſucceſſe. For what getteſt thou by all thy wordes, coū ſulting and diſputing but trouble? For where many wordes are there are many dreames &c. This is the vniuerſall propoſition ſimply conuerted. Where are many cogitations & diſputations, there are many dreames, where are many dreames, there are many wordes & diſputations.

The ſūme of this doctrine.The ſumme therfore of all is to feare God, and in thyne harte to reuerence & worſhip him. So Paule commaundeth the wife to feare her huſband, that is, ſo to reuerence him, that ſhée committe nothing that may offend him. Euen ſo ſhall we feare God, that is we ſhall reuerence him, and doe or commit nothing that ſhall offend him. This he meaneth: Neyther conſent thou to them that are too carefull, nor to thoſe yt are too careles. Be thou neyther impious Deſpiſer, nor preſumptuous Counſeller & Searcher.

Here now is ye ende of this place and admonitiō, not to be offended at ye courſe of this lyfe, Neyther (fayth he) diſpute nor contemne, but reuerence God, and think that it is Gods doing. &c. For god thus doth all thinges, to confound our deuiſes, and our fleſh, and to declare that he is God. &c. For the fleſh is eyther to carefull, or to contemptuous. Thus Salomon in the myddle of his oration taketh care to put away offence, leaſt any ſhould be offended at his doctrine, and eyther neglect his buſines, or preſume to much of him ſelfe. Therefore he counſelleth vs to performe our vowe, that is
to feare God, and keepe his commaundement.

The Scripture vnderſtandeth by a vowe not onely Ceremoniales,What the Scripture vnderſtandeth by vowing. but the whole ſeruing of God. as Dauid ſayth: pſalme 49. Pay thy vowes to the highheſt, Likewiſe that the Iewes cried out: All the thinges that God hath commaunded, we will doo. This was a very great vowe: Euē ſo thou ye haſt promyſed to perfourme his will, ſtand to this vow, letting paſſe all other thinges, which God will not haue the to ſearche or care for. Now returneth he to the rehearſall of mens affayres.

div.head: If in a countrey thou ſeeſt the oppreſſion of the poore, and the defrauding of iudgment and iuſtice, be not aſtonied at the matter. For he that is higher then the higheſt regardeth, and there be higher then they, and the King is ouer all the earth, ſo ſe the ground tylled.
div.p:
AFter this treatye of godlynes,An admonition agaynſt the offēce takē when good men are oppreſſed. he returneth agayne trymly to his Roll of vanities, where he repeteth one thinge oftentimes as is vſed in Sermones.
This he ſayth. I bad you feare God, or els you ſhuld do no good, yea you would ſay, there is no God, onleſſe you were armed with the feare of God and knowledge of the truth. For when you ſée the poore oppreſſed and iudgment ſubuerted here you will murmure, what vnrighteouſnes will you ſay is this? where is god become? why ſuffereth he theſe thinges? againſt theſe cogitations and offences, Salomon confirmeth vs, feare thou God ſayth he, and thinke there is a iudge appoynted for it, he ſhall redreſſe it. If thou canſt not amend the Iudge, thinke this is the courſe of this world and howe no man is able to cauſe all Iudges to be iuſt, this onely is in Gods power, the high Kinge.

None vnderſtand theſe thinges, but thoſe that haue beene in office. I haue ſeene and prooued in the Monaſtery, how many vniuſt mē haue béene put in office, which thing yet coulde not be remedyed. So Doctour Sulpitius beyng very wylling and deſirous to put good men in euery office,The ſaying of Doctour Sulpitius. and yet could not, was wont to ſay: men muſt goe to the plough with ſuch horſſes as they haue: he that hath
no horſſe, muſt goe to plough with Oxen according to the prouerbe.Good politike men are rare. So it fareth in worldly affayres: Sometyme there is a good Prince, but he is not able to ſée that all Preſidentes and Iudges be good and iuſt men, and yet he is compelled to haue officers. So wiſe men haue great care to make good lawes for the commons, that they ſhould be obediēt, but yet they murmure and complaine of the force, and vnrighteouſnes of the Iudges. &c.

When thou ſéeſt ſuch thinges,The offēce taken of naughty gouerning the commō weale. thinke theſe be the vanities of this worlde, and flye not out of the worlde as the Monkes doe into ye wildernes. For they fare like the huſbandman that hath fierce horſſes, and will geue them vp, where rather he ſhould vſe all kinde of diligence to tame and breake thē. So there be ſome ſo froward & wayward houſholders, ſo ſharpe exactors of worke, that they doe nothing but diſturbe the whole houſe with theyr vnreaſonablenes.The ſaying of Frederike ye third Emperour. This is a notable ſaying of Frederike the third which was Emperour: He that can not deſſemble, cā not be an Emperour. Adde this, he that knoweth not how to diſſemble, knoweth not how to liue. If thou wylt •
liue in the world, learne to ſée this.

The doctrine of this booke is, that in the commō miſeries of this life, we ſhould keep faith faſt, & a good cō ſcience, and quyet hart in God.Then let vs doe nothing. Not ſo: We muſt labour and be doing: but that thou canſt not bring to paſſe, diſſemble. Thus it behooueth a wiſe houſholder, to diſſemble, and make as he knew not of diuers thinges that offend him: For it is impoſſible that all thinges can be done well & rightly. This booke therefore teacheth peace and quietnes of mynde, in theſe worldly affayres, that when thou ſéeſt or heareſt of euils thou ſhouldeſt not vexe thy ſelfe, but ſay, this is the courſe of the worlde. It goeth none otherwiſe here. Againe, when thou ſeeſt thinges goe wel, to ſay: Bleſſed be God, which ſo ordreth theſe thinges, that not onely he ſuffreth euill to be done, but intermedleth good with euill. Doe thou that thou art able, the reſt commit vnto God, and according to the prouerbe: He that can not lyfte vp the heauy ſtone, muſt let it lie ſtill, and let him take vp the ſtone that he is able. Therfore when thou ſéeſt euill in Princes, Officers abuſe their authoritie, Iudges geue wrong iudgemēt, the commons murmure, and wiſe men diſpute, thinke God will redreſſe this geare.

div.head: Let not this matter trouble thee.
div.p: HE goeth about to quiet and pacifye our mynde: Maruell not ſayth hée, though thou ſée ſuch thinges but be conted. Thou art not able to remedy theſe thinges, for thou canſt not helpe or better them: wherfore feare God, and commit the matter vnto him, ſo ſhalt thou be quyet. He that will not thus doe, ſhall finde nothing but trouble.

div.head: For he that is higher thē the higheſt regardeth.
div.p:
THat is, doe not thou vexe thy ſelfe,That God is ye reuēger of all wickednes. if thou canſt not redreſſe it, leaue it to an higher Iudge. That, that the inferior is not able to compaſſe, let him thynke it belongeth to the ſuperior. If the Prince be euill, complayne of it to an higher power, euen to God. So if I ſhoulde vexe my ſelfe much about the ſchiſmes and ſectes which diſturbe the Church, and contaminate the Goſpell, what ſhould I preuaile? Therfore I commit the matter to God that is the Iudge, in whoſe hand are all thinges. Notwithſtandyng I am ſory that the ſoules of men are ſo miſerably ſeduced and deceaued, but I cā
doe no more but according to myne office reſiſte them, and ſay leaue of, you haue erred long inough, repent. When thou haſt thus counſelled an other, then commit him to God, according to Pauls ſaying: Him that is an heretike, after one or two admonitions, ſhunne and auoyde. &c. Agayne: wicked men waxe worſe and worſe. For they ſhall not eſcape their Iudge. Euery one hath hys Iudge, if the Bailiffe doeth it not, the Sheriffe or Maior will doe it. And if he will not iudge them, the king ſhall, if the kyng regarde it not, the Emperour ſhal. If the Emperour will not, God wil not contemne or neglect it. This is it that he meaneth: The king is ruler ouer all the earth. Salomon had no higher office thē a kynges: Let the kyng bring to paſſe that thou art not able.

div.head: To ſee the grounde tylled.
div.p:
Wherfore the Magiſtrate is ordeyned of God.THis ſéemeth to be as an adiection, or addition to a kyngly eſtate. Wherby is ſignified to what office he is appointed and what charge is of the ſecular power. To this ende (ſayth he) is he ordayned a Magiſtrate and officer, to ſée the earth be
tylled, to reuenge the iniuries & wrongs of inferiors. The kyng hath the ſworde, to defend the innocent, and to puniſhe the malefactour, and God ſuffereth no wickednes on the earth which he puniſheth not by the magiſtrate. If the inferior officer doth it not, yet the higher doth: It cō meth at length to the power of ye ſworde.

This is notable that he calleth ye kyng a tyller of the ground:The dutie of kynges. which thing ſignifieth not onely the tyllage of the earth, but the whole maintenaunce of the common weale, which conſiſteth of lawes, iudgementes. &c. For it is a kynges duty aſwel to defend, as to make prouiſion for victuals, and other neceſſaries. Tyllage prepareth foode, warre, or the ſworde defendeth vs, kéepeth vnder the malefactor, that other may ply their tyllage, and doe that they ought. So it lyeth in the kyng, as well to make prouiſion for neceſſaries as to ſée them conſerued. For vnles he defend them, other can not follow theyr tyllage. Thus Salomon both armeth vs againſt offēces, and alſo teacheth vs that our deuiſes are but vayne. I (ſayth he) am a kyng by Gods appointmēt, and albeit I am not able to redreſſe all things,
yet I doe as much as I am able: the reſt I am cōpelled to beare and ſuffer, leaſt ye whole land ſhould be left waſte, cōmending all things in ye meane while to God the high Iudge, who hath all the power of the ſword in his hand. Thus let euery man in his calling doe what he is able, and commit the reſt to the higher power.

div.head: He that loueth ſiluer ſhall not be ſatiſfied with ſiluer, and he that loueth riches, ſhall be without the fruite therof: this alſo is a vanitie. When goods increaſe, they are increaſed that eate them: and what good cōmeth to the owners thereof, but the beholding of them with their eyes?
div.p:
The vice of couetouſnes.THis belongeth to that he ſayd in the firſt chapiter: The eare is not ſatiſfied with hearing, nor the eye with ſeing. Here he treateth of the vanitie and deſires of mans hart. One worlde was not inough for Alexander. So fareth it in all other affayres, honours, ryches. &c. For ſo goeth the miſerable life of man, that a couetous man is an example to all men. He hath money, and yet
is he not ſatiſfied, yea he enioyeth it not being preſent,What a couetous man is. onely he thyrſteth after other that he hath not.

What els therfore is a couetous man, but an hart ſtretched out to that it hath not, and turned from that it hath? Therfore this is a vanitie of the hart: were it not better to be content with things preſent, and to caſt of the care of thinges to come? Souldiours are happier then couetous men, although they be the worſte of all other men, & liue moſt hardly. For els all men be couetous, except ſuch in whom other lyke vices put couetouſnes away. But the godly onely haue this benefite, that they are contēted with things preſēt, and can vſe them alſo with mirth and thankes geeuing. A couetous man hath no greater mouth, belly, &c. then a godly poore man, nor digeſteth no more then he, and yet is he contented with a litle, yea he is riche, where the couetous in the middle of his riches is a begger. Theſe things men are taught both holeſomly and godlyly, but the fleſhe is careles ſay we, or doe we, what we will.The goods of the couetous conſumed by others.

div.head: Where much goods are. &c.
div.p:
THis is a notable ſentence: The couetous man is neuer filled, but ſtill gathereth. To whom? A niggard requireth a prodigall. For although he haue neuer ſo much money, yet is it conſumed either in his life tyme, or when he is dead, neither hath he any thing of it but ſorrow & trauell. Kyng Salomon hath his houſes full of ſiluer and golde, but who vſeth them? His Courteours. He onely is but fed & apparelled therwith. Who haue ye vſe of Princes goods, in princes Courts? Souldiours,What it is to gather riches. wryters, braggers, & other gay knaues. Therefore to gather riches together, is to gather together many waſters and conſumers. Why then vexeſt thou thy ſelfe with ſuch ſcraping all thinges togither? Be content with that thou haſt. For if thou wilt néedes gather riches, they wil not come without gheſts that will deuour them, if not in thy lyfe tyme, yet after thy death. Thou haſt naught els of all thy goods, but to fill thy mouth & thy belly, and to cloth thy back. If riches encreaſe, take thy part of them, leaue the reſt vnto others, and laye aſide thy carefull gathering and ſcraping. If thou wilt not ſo doe, yet ſhall it be done.
For thou heareſt here: Where much goods are, there are many to eate and conſume them.

div.head: And what good commeth to the Owners thereof. &c.
div.p:
THis is an egregious mocking of Couetouſnes. Horace ſayth: Thou lyeſt gaping & ſleping ouer thy bagges rounde about thee, and art compelled to ſpare thē as though they were ſome religious ſtuffe, and haſt none other ioye in them, but as in certen paynted Tables. The ſame ſayth alſo: Amonges all thy hourds and heapes of riches, a very begger. The ſame ſaying hath Salomon: A Couetous man hath none other commoditie, but to behold his florens, as I behold a paynted table, any thing more he hath not. A couetous mā can not vſe his mony to that ende it was ordayned, namely to eate, drinke and clothe himſelfe, and to ſerue other mens turnes with the reſt. For to this ende groweth wyne, corne, golde, and ſiluer, yt we ſhould thus vſe it. But the fleſhe careth not, but foloweth her owne deſires. Wherefore this followeth
of it, that he leadeth a miſerable lyfe, without reſt or quyet.

div.head: The ſleepe of him that traueleth is ſweet, whether he eat litle or much but the ſacietie of the rich will not ſuffer him to ſleepe.
div.p:
SAlomon procedeth in condēning riches, that is to ſay, the carke and care of gathering and keeping of riches. For the more a couetous body gathereth riches, the more his mynde is deſyred and enflamed. Alwayes a couetous body is in neede, and in the myddle of his goodes wanteth, yea couetouſnes is ſuch a monſter ſayth Saluſt, that neither with plenty, nor daintye it is diminiſhed. And as an other ſayth: The loue of money encreaſeth, euen as the money it ſelfe encreaſeth. Among theſe miſeries of a couetous man, he rehearſeth yet one other. Though a couetous man be neuer ſo full, yet he can not ſleepe. So that all maner of waies a couetous mans lyfe is miſerable, being at reſt neyther day nor night. For nature hath ſo ordeyned that the body being temperately dyeted and refreſhed, ſleapeth ſweetely and quietly.
For Drūkards neyther ſléepe nor wake, being nether deade nor alyue. And he ye laboureth moderately, ſleepeth quietly, although he eate but a lytle, as was ſaid: Man goeth furth to his labour vntill the Euening. The couetous continueth his labour, euen vntill midnight wearieng, and breaking his body. The body therefore of the couetous ouercharged with meate, and tyred with labour, and the mynde troubled with cares, will not let him to ſleepe, or take reſt.Moderate labour commaunded. Therfore ſeing Salomon ſayth to him that laboureth, he commaundeth to labour, & forbyddeth not to get goods. And where he ſayth: Sleepe is ſweete, he requireth moderate labour, ſuch as exerciſeth the body, but tyreth it not. Therfore he appointeth to labour, and forbyddeth to be couetous and carefull. For the bleſſing of the Lord maketh rich men, and not continuall toyle and labour, as is ſayde in the 126. Pſalme. It is but loſte labour that you riſe ſo early, &c. Againe Thus God geueth his beloued ſleepe. Thus Abraham, Iſaac, Iacob, Dauid, Salomon, were made rich through gods gyft and bleſſing. And they ſo vſed their
riches, that other were relieued alſo by them.

How we ought to vſe our goods.Wherefore riches are not to be caſt away, Offices are not to be geuen ouer, as Epicures haue taught, the wife is not to be caſt of, nor the familye to be forſaken, but we muſt take paine, and be content. We muſt be doing among others, and take in good part whatſoeuer God ſendeth. In what ſtate God hath placed thée, there remaine, onely ſée thou go not about, to rule al things after thine owne preſcription. In that ſtate, what hurte happeneth not to thee, take that for a vantage. For this lyfe is ſo variable, ye we may euery day looke for ſome euil or myſhap. As for proſperitie and good hap, commeth without our expectation. But when it commeth, we muſt geue God thankes for it, as for ſome ſingular benefit. If we chaunce of an honeſt wyfe: if we happen to haue obedient children, let vs thanke God of it. If the magiſtrate rule the cōmon weale well and orderly, if the fielde yeld his increaſe &c. we muſt take all for a vauntage. But if it happen otherwiſe, vexe not, frett not thy ſelfe. Thus Salomon will not take vs out of
the worlde, but ſet vs forward in it,A doctrine how we ought to vſe our goods, and to beare the common miſeries of this life. leaſt we ſhould imagine him to be like to Cratis or Diogines, which were fooliſh deſpiſers of the worlde, and of riches. For this is but an impious ſaying of ye Philoſophers, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Lyue lyke an hydden and vnknowen man. For when they ſawe the world was ruled vniuſtly they thought it beſt to lyue ſolitaryly, & not to meddle with publyke affayres, leaſt they ſhould be compelled to ſée and ſuffer ſuch vnrighteouſnes. This ſaying of vſing and bearing with ye world was vnknowen and hidden from all the Philoſophers. But ſeing we haue Salomon to teach vs, let vs doo what we are able, and that we are not able to doo, let vs let paſſe.

div.head: I haue ſeene an euill ſicknes vnder the ſunne, to wyt, ryches conſerued to the owners for their euill. And theſe riches periſh by euell trauell, and he begetteth a ſonne, and in his hand is nothing.
div.p:
THis alſo is a moſt vaine miſery in ye life of man, not come in deede to all men, but yet ſuch as is dayly ſéene, how
ryches are reſerued to the myſchiefe of ye maſter and gatherer.The goods of many are hurtful to ye owners. Salomon complaineth that this is not onely a myſery in ſuch men, but alſo yt we ſee ſuch thinges come to paſſe in the world, though we be free from them.Examples. For how many haue ben priuely ſlayne in their owne howſes, in our dayes, bycauſe of their riches. Had not the Duke of Bauarie in our dayes a great maſſe of golde,George Duke of Bauarye. a tower ful of gold? But this golde purchaſed warre vnto ye Duke, and calamitie to the whole land. And ſcarſe any Princes haue left greate riches behinde them, but they haue bene the deſtruction of the whole Countrey, as Iulius Caeſar turned the Treaſurye of Rome to the deſtruction of the Citye. Our Byſhoppes gathered treaſure together, but onely for a myſchiefe, for none was the better for them, & that cauſeth the Burroes, and people of the Contrey to ryſe. Now alſo they hold on in gathering, and fleecing of the people, but they will not leaue, till ſuch come as ſhall take from them that they gather, with their owne deſtruction.

Shall we not yet caſt riches awaye? No rather we muſt prepare riches, ſpecially
Princes,We muſt get goods, but to our owne and others godly vſes. but to thende to vſe them and relieue others, which becauſe we do not, therefore God ſuffreth for a puniſhment thoſe riches wherein they put their truſt, to be the deſtruction of the owners. So Ezechiel prophecieth againſt the couetous and wicked Iewes. They reached not out their hand to the poore, therefore they ſhall be led into Captiuitye, and periſhe with their riches. The ſame ſhall happen to other rich mē, couetous Byſhops, and contempners of the goſpel,That that Chriſt will not take, the Chequere will. becauſe they will not lett the poore haue ye vſe of their riches, ye Souldiers and Checquere ſhall come, & take that that Chriſt receiueth not.

div.head: They periſh with great calamitie.
div.p: HE ſuffereth greate miſery. At home he is euery day in daūger of théeues, abroad of Robbers, he is takē and killed. This ſong marchant mē know ful well.

div.head: And his borne of hym ſhall haue no poſſeſſion of him.
div.p:
THe reaſon is, becauſe Sodome & Gomorra haue riches, but they reach not their hand to the poore: therefore ye Lord
ouerturneth them &c. The couetous gathereth, and an other deſtroyeth that he gathereth. The couetous thinketh: my ſonne ſhall haue theſe riches, but lo God ſendeth théeues & Robbers, which turne him out of all he hath, ſo that neyther he nor his ſōne haue any thing left.Apply thy labour and aſke and looke for good ſucceſſe of God. Wherfore we muſt follow labour, but looke for the bleſſing of God, and reléeue the poore and néedy: yea all our labour muſt be yt in the harueſt, and at ye grape gathering, we muſt ſing and labour, and in the middell of our labour and ſweate be meary, and ſo affected, that we can be content to forgoe all with a good will, thinkinge thus: I will labour for me and my children, If God ſend vs any thing, we will vſe it. If any thing be left, let my ſonne haue it after me, If nothing, God will finde him & prouide for him, as he hath donne for me.

div.head:
Euen as he came naked out of his mothers belly, ſo ſhall he returne naked againe as he came, and ſhall beare away nothing of his labour. This is a vaine and miſerable thing that in all pointes as they came
they ſhall goe againe: & what profite hath he, that he hath trauelled for the wynde?
div.p: THis alſo is in Iob. the firſt chapiter:How we ſhould vſe our goods. Naked I came out of my mothers wombe. &c. Againe in Paul 1. Tim. 6. We brought nothing (ſaith he) into the worlde, neither ſhall we carry any thing out of the worlde. The rycheſt man in the worlde, can glory in no more, but that he hath eaten and dronkē of his goods while he lyued. &c. Since therefore we carry nothing with vs, let vs beſtow it on other, and vſe our riches, as we vſe running water and the ayre. Let hym thinke thus: As when I dye I ſhal leaue my riches, euē ſo ſhall I doe while I am lyuing. Why then ſhould I ſo carefully gather goods, ſince I ſhal haue but a morſell of them my ſelfe. The water I vſe thus, I waſhe me therwith, ſo doe other. Looke what we doe not néede, the ſame doe we ſuffer to paſſe by vs. So vſe I fire and the ayre. And ſo ought we to vſe ryches, as Stewardes and beſtowers of them onely.

div.head: What profite hath he that he hath trauelled for the wynde?
div.p: To labour agaynſt the wynde.TO labour againſt the winde is an Hebrew phraſe, which Paul hath imitated. 1. Cor. 9. I ſo fight not, as one that beateth the ayre: And in ye 1. to ye Cor. the 14. You ſhall be as mē that ſpeake in the wynde. It ſignifieth as much as to ſpeake in vayne. So ſayth Salomon: A couetous man laboureth in the wynde, that is, in vayne: It is all l • ſt labour.

div.head: All the dayes of his lyfe he eateth in darkenes, with much griefe, ſorrow and anger.
div.p: What lyght and darkenes ſignifieth in the Hebrewe toung.AGayne, this is a phraſe of the Hebrewes. He eateth in darknes, for he eateth in ſadnes. It is taken from the geſture & countenaunce of men: for whē the hart is heauy, then the eyes are ouercaſt, as it were with a cloude. But when it is meary then is it lightened as it were with certeine beames, and a newe lyght. This phraſe is very often in the Pſalm, light for mirth, and darkenes for ſadnes, as in the 27. Pſalme: The Lord is my light, and my ſaluation. Againe: Lighten myne eyes. &c.

To eate therefore in drunkennes, is
to labour in ſadnes. A couetous Artificer findeth alwayes ſome matter to offende him and to chide at,What it is, to eate in darcknes. becauſe he is full of cares and heauines. he can not eate hys bread in mirth, he is alway chyding, he alway findeth ſomewhat in his familye that greueth him. So before the Prince and Magiſtrate are brought no matters but euill, there the vnwiſe magiſtrate vexeth himſelfe with care, becauſe he ſeeth his care and ſtudy taketh no better ſucceſſe. But the wyſe ruler ſayth thus: I doe and geeue the beſt counſell that I can, I ſuffer that I can not redreſſe, and am compelled ſo to doe, leauing it vnto God, which onely knoweth how to correcte all thinges at his pleaſure, and to proſper our counſels.

So it gréeueth vs to heare among ſo many preachers, ſo few faithfull & good, & which loue their charge with all their hartes. But what ſhall we doe? Shall we vexe and fret our ſelues away wyth ſorrow therefore? No not a whit. But let vs commit the matter vnto God. &c. We muſt therefore acquaint our eyes & eares to ſee & heare thoſs euils that we woulde not, and not thinke to heare and
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
ſée the goodnes, which woulde lyke vs. The worlde will not ſuffer this geare. He that woulde haue nothing to offende hym, ſhall finde more thinges than any other to offende him. Therefore let vs ſo fence our ſelues againſt all theſe euils, that we may know this is the courſe of this lyfe. &c.

div.head: Therefore I ſee it is good for a man to eate and drinke, and to be meary in all his trauell that he taketh vnder the Sun, all the dayes of his life that God geueth him: for this is his portiō. But this is the gift of God, when he hath geuen man ryches and ſubſtance, and power to eate & drinke his part therof, and to reioyce in his labour.
div.p:
The concluſion of the whole booke oftē times repeated.THis is the concluſion of all this booke or diſputation, declared alſo before in the ſecond and third chapiters. And here thou ſéeſt that Salomō doth not cōdemne riches, nor forbid vs to get riches, eyther meate or drinke, but calleth them ye gifts of God, to teach vs to caſt our cares away, to looke for all theſe things at gods hand by fayth, and when God will: patiently
to take the loſſe of them, as Abraham gaue his ſonne vnto God. Therfore riches muſt not be caſt away: for God doth not geue vs them to that end, to caſt them away, or to abſteyne from them, but rather to vſe and deale them to thoſe that néede. This ſentēce is the interpretation of the whole booke, that Salomon forbiddeth all vaine cares, that we ſhould vſe things preſēt mearily, being nothing carefull for things to come, leaſt we loſe our preſent benefite and commodity.

div.head: For this is his portion. &c.
div.p: THat is, the ſame is all that he hath of it. For he remembreth not the dayes of his lyfe. That is, his hart is not vexed with cares and heauines, neyther of thinges paſt, ne yet to come: becauſe God cheareth his hart. &c. Thus hath he ioye in his labour, and in the middle of euils entreth into Paradiſe. But the vngodly and couetous, and as many as after thys example vſe not theſe worldly goods, beginne here to be tormented, and throwen into hell. &c.

div.head: The ſixt Chapiter.

This is alſo an euill vnder the Sun, and much vſed among men: A mā to whom God hath geeuen ryches and treaſures, and honour, & wanteth nothing for his ſoule of all that he deſireth, and yet God ſuffereth him not to eate thereof, but a ſtraunge man ſhall eate it vp. This is a vayne thing and a miſerable.
div.p:
Of what rich and couetous mā Salomon here ſpeaketh. AFter this doctrine and exhortation intermedled, he returneth to his rolle of the diuers deuiſes of mans lyfe, wherin vanitie and miſery raigneth. It ſéemeth lyke that he ſayd before of the rich man. But here he ſpeaketh of ſuch a rich mā as kéepeth much riches about hym, and a great family, liuing in reſt without loſſe of his goods, and yet in the middeſt of his honor and riches, is greeued, and can not enioye them, becauſe eyther he falleth ſicke, or is vexed with hatred & care how to kéepe and encreaſe his goods. So with that he hath he is moleſted, and periſheth. If he haue a ſonne, then cōmeth another care,
how he may leaue hym a rich man, whē he is of age. For as the prouerbe ſayth: for a ſmal childe there is but a ſmal care, for a great childe, great care. They gather for their childrē, they deſire to leaue them rich, to bring them to great honor. Theſe are the wiſhes and deſires of all mē, which yet are moſt vaine. For what is it for a mā in his life to haue al things, and yet to vſe nothing, but alwayes to gape after more, and that he hath not, not regarding that he hath?

He deſcribeth therfore ſuch a rich man as wanteth nothing to liue welthely and mearely with, and yet doth not ſo.What maner of riche man he deſcribeth in this place. Looke vpō many of our noble men which might liue commodiouſly vpon their owne, hauing aboundaunce of goods vppon theyr landes, yet not contented therewith, get them to Princes Courtes, and looke ſtill for more, lyuing moſt miſerablye. The lyke we may ſée in riche men and Marchaunts, who being able to lyue at home quietly, with great daunger of their life, and loſſe of their goods, make great vyages both by land and Sea. Is not this a vayne and miſerable trade? Therefore it followeth:

div.head: If he beget an hundreth children, and yet liue many yeares, and haue great riches al the dayes of his life, & yet his ſoule is not ſatiſfied with goods, and his body not buryed: I ſay that an vntymely fruite is better then he. For he commeth into vanitie, and goeth into darkenes, and his name ſhall be couered with darkenes.
div.p: The miſerable ſtate of couetous men.HE amplifieth ye miſery of a couetous rich man. Let no mā (ſaith he) thinke by ſparing, to enriche his heyres. For riches are the gift of God, and come not of our labour: for many labour carefully to get riches, & yet can not attayne to them. Againe many waxe riche, and haue takē no great payne for them, that a man may know riches are ye gyft of God. Neyther is it in thy power to leaue this or ye heyre riche: It is ment that poore men ſhal not be rich. Doe what thou wilt, thou ſhalt not enriche him whom God will haue to be poore. Furthermore it may come to paſſe, that this couetous rich man may dye, when he hath loſt all hys goods before.

div.head: And may want buryall.
div.p: HE holdeth on in exaggerating of hys myſery, that is, he may be forſakē of all his frendes, or dye in an other countrye, and not at home.

div.head: I ſay that an vntymely fruite is better then ſuch an one.
div.p: THat is, it were better he were not at all, then to be ſuch a miſerable man, and in ſuch great ſtore of goods, a begger. This is true without godlynes. Compare the lyfe of a couetous rich man, and a wretch with him that is not yet borne, and thou ſhalt perceaue it. And Salomō ſpeaketh not as fooles vſe to ſpeake, as ſome ſay of this place, but ſetteth out the lyfe of fooles, in the outward body. There it is better not to be borne then to liue in ſuch ſort: that is to ſay, to haue ryches, glory, children, long lyfe, and yet not to enioye them.

This therfore is truely vnderſtanded of a miſerable riche man,A rich man couecous is a miſer. who hath the thinges pertayning to felicitie, and yet hys wretched mynde will not ſuffer hym to vſe them. Surely a poore man that taketh his condition in good part, is better
then a rich: for the wayfaring man with neuer a penny in his purſſe, will ſing as he goeth by the way: but the rich man is afrayde of euery buſhe, and in great felicitie is a very begger. Therfore ye world is altogether ruled by opinions, but God ruleth in déedes. We are vexed with opinions, and loſe the things their ſelues, lyke to that dogge of Aeſops that we ſpake of.

div.head: For he commeth into vanitie, and goeth into darkenes.
div.p: THat is, naked, deſtitute of all thinges and néedy he came into the worlde, ſo he lyueth, and ſo he dyeth: becauſe he enioyeth not his goods, but onely is troubled with care and deſire of more. Thys is nought els, but to haue nothing, and to be bare and beggerly.

div.head: And his name ſhall be couered in darkenes.
div.p: THat is, he doth nothyng worthy of name, or commendable in his houſe, but onely it is ſayde of him, he was neyther his owne frende, nor other mens. Such a miſerable man, as no man would deſire to follow.

div.head: Alſo he hath not ſeene the Sunne nor can be quiet in any place.
div.p:
THis is an hebrewe phraſe,What this phraſe meaneth to looke on ye Sunne. to ſee the Sunne, to enioy & reioyce in thinges. For this corporall lyfe eſtéemeth yt
〈◊〉 as a certain holy and ſacred power, very neceſſary for man, without the which all thinges appeare and be ſad and lumpiſh as Chriſt alſo ſayth: He that walketh in the darke wotteth not whether he goeth: But he that walketh in the daye, ſtumbleth not, becauſe he ſeeth the light of this worlde. &c. It is a moſt ioyfull ſight therefore to haue the ſonne to ſhyne, but the couetous mā looketh not on the ſonne, conſidereth not the ſonne, that is, he thinketh not how good a thing the ſonne is, nor any other creature to vſe and enioy it well. For wt him all conſideration of the benefites and creatures of God is loſt, by reaſon of •• uetous deſires, he neuer ſeeth home goodly a gift of god yt ſun riſing euery day is. He myndeth nothing, he regardeth nothing, he ſigheth after nothing but money. So the ambitious man looketh after nothing but honours. The louer looketh
not vpon his owne wyfe, but alwayes vpon an other mans. That is, they vſe not Gods preſent goodes and creatures. Thus the vngodly beginne their hell in this lyfe, wherein they are depriued of ye vſe of all the creatures and giftes of god, ſo that they neuer ſee ye ſunne which yet we haue dayly before our eyes. &c. that i • , they reioyce not in Gods giftes, but ſtill ſéeke after their owne deſires.

div.head: Yea though he lyued two thowſād yeares, yet hath he no good lyfe. Come not all to one place.
div.p: The miſerie of a couetous man.SEe how he amplifieth this miſery of the couetous man: that is, he ſhall get nothing, but the •• nger he lyueth ye more his myſeryes and comunities are diſcreaſed. This is the lyfe of man, more vanitie and myſery, eyther ſuch as thou 〈◊〉 be •• thy ſelf, or 〈…〉 others. For euen the godly although they liue not after ye fleſh, yet the fleſhe • oubleth 〈◊〉 , and they are compelled to féele the 〈◊〉 of the fleſhe.

div.head: Doo not all thinges goe. &c.
div.p:
HE repeateth that he ſayd before in the firſt chapter, The ſonne ryſeth and
ſetteth, and draweth to his place where he riſeth.All things that haue beginning ſhall decay. The Ryuers returne to ye place from whence they flowed. One generation paſſeth away &c. All thinges returne whence they came. At length all thinges periſh. Mans lyfe, kingdomes, and whatſoeuer els belongeth to man, returneth from whence it came, from ye earth to the earth, euen as the winde bloweth to and fro, and as the ſonne returneth to ye place where he aroſe. This therefore is Salomons meaning, yt we muſt let go care and thought for thinges to come, and enioye the thinges preſent. Therefore he goeth on.

div.head: All the labour a man taketh is for him • elfe, and yet his ſoule is neuer ſatiſfied acording to her deſire
div.p:
IN the Hebrew it is, all the labour of man is for his mouth,A mouth wyth the Hebrewes ſignifieth a kynde of meaſure. by a a certen, phraſe peculiar to yt people. So Moſes, vſeth this worde mouth, for a quantitie or meaſure. Geneſ. 47. ſpeaking of Ioſeph. And he fedde them, and all his fathers houſe, geuing thē all meate, where in the hebrew it is: he had a care for euery mouth of them, that is, he prouided all
his fathers houſe of meate, as it had been litle children, which haue their meate geuen them and labour not. And in the 12. of Exod. You ſhall eate the Paſſeouer, according to the mouth of euery one, that is, according to the number of them that can eate a Lambe. So ſpeaketh Salomon here. Euery mans labor is according to his mouth, that is according to the meaſure and taſke of him, yt is, euery mā hath his certein labor. God graunteth to euery man his labour, according to his power, and according to his vocation, which we expreſſe in the Dutch toūg thus. Euery one hath ſoch parte as is appointed for hym. God hath meaſured to euery mā his portion. A childe muſt labour after one ſort, a mā after an other. A magiſtrate in one kind, a pryuate man in another. He will haue thee lyke an infant, exerciſed in infants doinges, and a Prince in highe & weighty affayres. Hereof commeth this Prouerbe. Such perſon, ſuch ſloppe or breeche.

Euery mā muſt apply his vocatiō.Thus he calleth vs frō ſtraunge cares to our owne vocation, not forbidding vs to labour, but declaring we muſt labour,
willing vs to goe chearefully forward wt our buſines, according to our taſke, and leaue other mens doings to themſelues. He will haue vs to take pleaſure, but in God, that we runne not at ryot with the vngodly, when we are in our pleaſure, nor he greued when pleaſure is wanting but to take all thing in good part. Reioice (ſayth he) in thy mynde, & take paine in body, ſo yet that yu kéepe wtin thy cōpaſſe, not lyke an enuious man, which ſéeketh after ye which is other mens. The marchaūt prayſeth the Souldier, ye Souldier recounteth his infelicitie & prayſeth the marchaunt. Olde men commend youth, we turne our eyes from ye pleaſures we haue of our owne, and with greate miſery, looke on other mens.Be content with thine owne eſtate No man can cō ſider his owne goodes nor lyue content wt his eſtate, for if they coulde ſo doo, they would not couet after other mens as they doo. For if olde men coſidered the daungers that are in youth, they would not wiſhe for youth. Agayne, if younge men ſawe the manifolde incommodities of age, they would beare their owne incōmodities the more willingly, & would not enuy old mē for their cōmodities. &c.

Who lyketh an others eſtate, hateth his owne.But thus we can not doo, but looke alwayes vpon other mens commodities, & deſpiſe our owne. So the couetous rych man hath an eye & deſire to that he hath not, and that he hath he neglecteth. For the ſoule is not filled, that is, abydeth not within his compaſſe. No man contēteth him with his condition. A beholder of an Interlude, thinketh he could play better then thoſe that playe. When I heare another preach I thinke I could farre paſſe him. The ſeruaunt likewiſe thinketh, if I were a kinge, I would gouerne all thinges prudentlie. So that fellow that is in Terence ſayth: I ſhould haue ben made a kinge. And yet if hee had had a kingdome, none would haue ſhewed him ſelfe a more foole then hee. It is cō monly ſayde: a morraine to him that doth better then he can. But the mind forgetteth his owne worke and is moſt buſie in another bodies, ſo doth he neither of bothe wel. For he that looketh not well to his owne charge, he will very ill looke to anothers. God hath geuen me occaſion to be occupied vpon mine owne, and in I leaue myne owne occupation, and buſye my ſelfe wt other mens. This
is truely • that he ſayd before. The eye is not ſatiſfied with ſeeing. &c. Euen ſo the ſoule or the harte, is not ſatiſfied with coueting, but is alway inconſtant and chaungeable.

div.head: For what hath the wyſe man more then the foole, or what profyteth it the poore, that he knoweth how to walke before the Lyuing.
div.p: THat is, couetouſnes,Of what wiſe men & fooles Salomō ſpeaketh. to haue more thē is appointed vs, troubleſh aſwell the wiſe men, as the fooles, & wyſe men herein doe nothing differ frō fooles. For both of them couet to much, and both of them couet that that other men haue. He vnderſtandeth ſuch men as be not wyſe in déede, but thoſe that be wyſe after a worldely ſorte. And by fooles, he meaneth wycked and vngodly men. The ſubtill craftie and reacheleſſe people.

Both of them (ſayth he) haue theyr trauel and labour appointed, beyond the which they ſhall be able to doo no good. The one will bring it as farre as the other. For one may thinke or ſay thus▪ if I were in office or auctoritie, I would doe many things, but if he were in deede
in office, he would doo as ly • le, as he y• is in office alreadye.

div.head: Or what profiteth it the poore?
div.p: HE vnderſtandeth by the lyuing, thoſe he ſpake of before: not onely thoſe yt haue lyfe, but thoſe that enioy the lyfe: that is, thoſe which liue welthely & well. He ſayth therefore yt it is a folyſh thing for priuate men, to preſcribe other how to order & gouerne all things, dreaming that they could doo all things better then other, where in déede there is nothinge donne, but that that ought to be.

div.head: The ſight of the eye is better then to walke after luſtes. This is alſo a vanitie and vexation of Spirite.
div.p:
A looking glaſſe.ALl this is an Hebraicall kinde of ſpeech to vs vtterly vnknowē. The Hebrue worde properly ſignifieth a looking glaſſe, yt is a thing comming toward our eyes or ſyght. For thus we reade in Exodus. 38. He made the Lauer of braſſe, and the foote of it of braſſe, of the looking glaſſes of the womē, that watched at the doore of the Tabernacle. This ſhould thus be tranſlated in
the hebrewe. He made a lauer &c. in the ſighte of thoſe that watched before the doore of the Tabernacle of wytneſſe. For this people had certen women votaries, which contynued in prayers and ſupplication, watching and ſeruyng God day & night, as we reade in the firſt of kynges, and ſecond of Luke, that Anna watched. Of this watching,Women watching in ye temple of the lord. the women were called the hoaſt of the Lord, watching before the doore of the tabernacle of witneſſe. Afterward in proceſſe of time, the religion decayed, and as Iudas ſaith, was turned into wātonnes. So of Rachel ye wyfe of Iacob it is ſayd, ſhee was comly to the glaſſe, that is, to ſight, or to looke vpon: ſhée was fayre or pleaſaunt in ſight. The meaning therefore is:We muſt enioy thinges preſēt, & not ſeeke. after things away. It is better to enioye ye things in ſight, & before our eyes, thē to wāder after our luſtes and deſiers, that is, vſe the thynges thou haſt, and let not thy witte wander about coueting of that, lyke Aeſops dogge, who catching at the ſhadow, loſt the meate in his mouth. That which God hath ſet as it were before thée, that vſe and be content, and follow not the deſire of thine hart, which can not be ſatiſfied,
as he ſayd before. Vnderſtand therfore by the ſight of the eyes, not ſuch as thine eyes make to thée, but ſuch as is made to them of other thinges, a paſſiue ſight: that is, vſe that that God for the time preſent geueth thee. Thus of God it is ſayd in the firſt of Gen. God ſawe all that he had made. &c. that is, he reioyſed in his workes, he ſtucke vnto them, he ſawe them, they pleaſed him, they were very good.

He reprehē deth vnſtable mindes, deſirous of other mens welfare.So he that is godly, cleaueth to that is his owne, and that that God hath geuen him for that tyme preſent lyketh & pleaſeth him. The vngodly doth not ſo, but is vexed with al he ſéeth, becauſe he vſeth it not as a glas, but wandereth ſtil in his mynde. Though he haue money, he is not delighted therewith, he enioyeth it not, but alwayes deſireth more. He hath one wyfe, and deſireth another: he hath one kingdome, and is not content therewith. Alexander looketh and deſireth for another worlde. All thinges ought to be as a looking glaſſe vnto vs, to delight in them, to fixe our eyes on them, to enioye them and geue God thankes for them. Therefore he forbiddeth vs to let our
ſoule wander about, (as it is in the Hebrewe) that is to occupie our myndes in the cogitations and opinions of worldly thinges, ſo that ye concluſiō of this whole place is: vſe the thinges thou haſt, and wander not about in diuerſe cogitations. for this is a vanitie, namely to let thy mynde wander and walke about.

div.head: What is that that hath beene? The name thereof is now named, and it is knowen that it is man: and he cā not ſtriue with him, that is ſtronger then he.
div.p:
BY the thinges gone before,There ſhal be alwayes vnſtable mē, couetous, & deſirous of other mens goods. this is ſufficiently vnderſtanded, for we ſpake of this phraſe before: What is that that is. &c. In all theſe wordes are Hebrewe phraſes, which thing we thus ſpeake in the Germaine toung: As it hath beene, ſo is it now: and as it is now, ſo will it be hereafter. That is, there ſhall be alwayes moſt vaine men, deſirers and wyſhers for vanities, becauſe they goe beyond the word of God, and their appointed ſtate. For they harken not to ye counſels of God. God hath made a differēce of men, & appointed to all men their boūds,
when they ſhall be borne,Euery mās trade of life is appointed of God. when they ſhal die, by what name they ſhall be called, & what office they ſhall beare: & when they are borne, he offreth them thinges to vſe preſētly & out of hand. But mē being not contented with the ordinaunce and counſell of God, chooſe them moſte tymes other wayes, and couet other thinges but in vayne. For none but God alone bringeth that to paſſe, that he thinketh or deuyſeth.

The meaning thereof is: What is that that is, &c. That is what is man now lyuing, or that ſhall be borne hereafter. Since that, that man is ordeyned to, is all ready appointed, & what name he ſhall haue. Vnderſtand here, that name, that he hath by his déedes, whereof he ſhall be called, as ye name of Caeſar is to be a Conquerour, the name of Catiline, a Murtherer of his owne Countrymen &c. Theſe names I ſay are ſo appoynted, & ſo called with God before we were borne. Euen ſo it was appoynted yt one ſhould be a ſhowmaker, one a pariſh prieſt, another a preacher &c. If therefore theſe names & offices were appointed and knowen before, why doth man
wander about in his owne opinions why taketh he ſo many thinges in hande, and deſyreth ſuch exceſſe? Why meddleth he beyond his boundes and marke? For he doth nothing but trouble him ſelfe more and more.

div.head: For he can not ſtriue with him that is ſtronger then he.
div.p:
THat is with the thing that is aboue his reach.All thinges ordeyned & appointed of God. For all thinges haue their foundation vpon Gods lawe and ordynaunce. The very heathens ſawe that thinge were not gouerned by the counſell of the wyſe, but attributed the doing to deſteny, or to fortune, and not to God. So Salomon in this place hath an eye to the courſe of this world. As thinges doe paſſe in the world. There he ſéeth, that mē can not compaſſe & bring to paſſe that they deſyre & take in hand. The reaſon is, becauſe the ſelfe ſame things withſtād them. They will not be in ſubiection nor be ruled by our coūſels, As if one would ſtriue to haue his owne deuyſe to goe forward he preuayleth not, the thing wythſtandeth hym, God ſtoppeth him. In vayne therefore we wince agaynſt the
prick, to as ſmall purpoſe as if we would runne through a wall with our head. For that that is ſtronger then he, and aboue him withſtādeth his deuiſe, as Anthony would haue braſt through his enemies, when he came into Italy, and made his two ſonnes kinges, one of the Eaſt, the other of the Weſt, but he was diſapointed thereof. Sée how Caeſar was put by his cogitations and deuiſe. Neyther hath the Popes enterpriſes ſuccéeded: becauſe their names were geuen them before and apointed, they went beyond their boundes. So they ſtraue agaynſt a ſtronger then they, and ſo gat nothing therby, but care, ſorrow, and calamitie.

Be content wyth thine eſtate.Becauſe therefore thou ſéeſt that all thinges are appointed by a lawe and ordinaunce, both thy name and office, and yet not contented therewith, ſtriueſt againſt it, thou roweſt againſt ye ſtreame, & ſhalt not preuaile, although thou counfell and dooſt many things neuer ſo wiſely, but onely multiplieſt words: nothing more will come of it ſauing that it may he talked of. Thus Plato wrott many thinges, ſo did Ariſtotle lykewiſe touching
the ordering & gouerning of common weales &c. but they are but mere words, and remayne wordes whereof nothyng followeth. Afterwarde when they ſawe they could not preuaile, they were deſirous to helpe ye matter with other lawes and deuiſes, and ſayd, would to God we had taken this way firſt, beyng wyſe too late.

Therefore the ſtories aſwel of ye Gentiles as of the Iewes teach vs, that men beyond their appointed ſtente & boundes can doo nothing,The doctrine comming by hiſtories. whether they be wiſe or fooliſhe, but the ſtories of ye Iewes were donne in the worde of God, and teach vs that all thinges are donne by Gods ordinance, and therefore it is good for vs to ſticke to them. Otherwiſe the ſtoryes of the Gentiles are as great and wonderful as they, but donne beſide ye word of God.

div.head: For who knoweth what is good for mā liuing in the dayes of his vaine lyfe, which is but a ſhadow? Or who will tell a man, what ſhall happen after him vnder the Sonne?
div.p:
THat is, no mā knoweth what is good for him in this lyfe. They know not
how to enioye their goodes,No man knoweth what is expedient for him in thys lyfe. nor howe to ſettle and quiet their mynde. Mens deuiſes are variable. One ſéeketh for rule, another for riches, and yet they know not, whether they ſhal haue. They enioy neither the thinges they haue, nor thoſe they wiſhe. Onelye they deſyre that cōmoditie and felicitie, that they neyther haue nor ſée. This is a generall concluſion vpon al men. None knoweth what is méete and conuenient for him. So Cicero and Demoſthenes, whē they had written much of a common weale, and would haue ſet ye ſame forward with their deuiſes, they moſt vnluckelie gouerned the ſame. The monkes alſo and Papiſtes would rule al the worlde, & lo they ſeduce it, & drowne it in greuous daungers & déepe darknes.

div.head: Or who ſhall tell a man what ſhall happen. &c.
div.p:
The ſucceſſe of thinges is not in our power.HE ſpeaketh not of that that ſhal happen after this lyfe, but what is lyke ſhortly after to follow the vſe of thinges preſent. There no man knoweth what is to come, whether Antony ſhall lyue or not, whether Brutus and Callius ſhal haue the victorie or not, whē Iulius came
to be Emperour, he deuiſed how to eſtabliſh and make ſure the kingdome to him and his, but he periſhed in the myddeſt of his cogitations, why then ſo trouble we our ſelues with ſuch thoughtes, ſeing thinges to come be at no tyme in our appointing and power? Let vs therefore be content with things preſent, and commit our ſelues to the handes of God, who alone hath knowen, and doth knowe to rule and gouerne both things paſſed, and thinges to come.

div.head: The Seuenth Chapter.
A good name is more worth then a precious oyntement, and the day of death is better then the daye of byrth.
div.p:
THis place ſéemeth harde becauſe of ye ignoraunce of the Hebrewe tounge,Conſolations and exhortations, entermedled in the accompte of vanities. which hath her figures that cā not be vnderſtāded but after the vſe of the tounge: and it ſéemeth no maner of way to agrée with the thinges that are gonne before. Me thinketh that this is the ſumme and meaning of the place, that Salomon will
comfort men that are impatient in theſe vaine deuiſes, as hetherto he hath done after he hath recited a ſort of worldly vanities, to intermire ſome conſolation and exhortation to the feare of God, that our hart might reare it ſelfe vp vnto God to harken to his worde, and not to be to ſwift of our toung. &c. So here againe he intermedleth a certaine exhortation after his reherſed Roll, meaning afterward to returne to his Roll agayne.

An exhortation to patience.Let this place therfore ſerue for a place of exhortation or conſolatiō for the impatient man, inſerted and ſet in the mydle of the reherſall of vaine deſyres and deuiſes. For in this life the hart of man findeth nothing but offences, and impatiencie ſpecially thoſe that are good men, becauſe as he ſayd before: He that ioyneth knoledge to him ſelfe, ioyneth to labour. He that heareth and ſéeth many thinges, hath occaſion to take much indignation, and ſorrow, Becauſe he ſéeth and findeth that it vexeth his hart. Looke vpō Timon who did degenerate into a beaſt, and became a manhater, and enemye of mankinde, after he perceaued he had nothing but enuye and perſecution, for the greate
benefites he beſtowed vpon his countrye men. The lyke might happen againe to an other, ſéeing of all his labour and trauell, he reapeth naught but vnkindenes. For his harte may be ſo broken, that he he will leaue of and trauell no more.

Theſe thinges Salomon ſpeaketh of good mē which deſire ye all thinges ſhould doo well.Many wearyed with ye malice and ingratitude of men, leaue their vocation. Such as are magiſtrates & gouernours ouer houſholdes, not of fooles which regarde not wiſedome, nor care not how the world goeth. For they that are gouernours of the cōmon weale and Rulers of families fynde great deceite & falſhode in men. This thinge hath frayed many men from intermedling with publyke Offices, So that olde man in Terence counted it an happy thing to be without a wyfe. An other againe ſayd: I haue maried a wife, what miſery haue I founde therein, children come, cares encreaſe. &c. Mans mynde is offended with all theſe things, vnleſſe it be armed aforehand with the worde of God. Therfore they that ſaw theſe things, ſayd: He lyueth well that liueth cloſe and hid. &c. But Chriſtians muſt be exhorted to liue in ye middle of theſe troubles, to marry
wiues, to rule their familie. &c. And if their purpoſes ſhall be interrupted through the naughtines of man, to take it patiently, and not to leaue of a good worke. Forſake not thy ſtanding, but abide in it. Be not diſcouraged with ſorrow or impatience, nor ouercommed of anger. This is therefore a ioyfull & very godly exhortation, but ſuch as none géeueth eare to, but only ye true Chriſtians.

A good name is not gotten, but with great labour, and bearing of many troubles.He beginneth this conſolation with a prouerbe, ſaying: Better is a good name. &c. after his accuſtomed maner: for Salomon is full of prouerbes. This is it he meaneth: I haue now rehearſed ſo many vanities in mās lyfe, that a mā might deſpaire & wiſhe rather to die, thē to ſée & ſuffer ſo many miſeries & calamities, or els to geue ouer all paines taking, and to doe nothing: but not ſo, geue not ouer, but holde on. Fare not as one that looketh for no name & fame: thinke that thou ſhalt purchaſe thy ſelf a name, if thou continue in thy ſtāding, whether thou be publike or priuate perſon. Beholde what a ſluggiſhe life they leade, which liue for themſelues alone. Therfore be not ouercomē of theſe aduerſities
but ſtand againſt them. For it is better thou prooue a man of great name, an example to other, or cōmoditie to thy ſelfe, then to be an idle & ſinggiſhe drone, profitable to no body: for a good name happeneth not to idle perſons & ſluggards, but to ſtoute and couragious men: Such as be couragious & wreſtle, thorow. S. Hierom reprehēded. &c. S. Hierome, becauſe he would ſeeme to flie the worlde and company of people, fled frō Rome and came to Bethlehem, becauſe he would liue here a ſolitary mā, and yet he was deſirous of a name, but his hart was not firme & ſtrong inough. For he was very impatient, and had nothing leſſe then a manly courage.A good name compared to an odorifecous oyntment.

He ſaith therefore that a good name is better then a precious oyntment. Name in this place againe ſignifieth fame. And this prouerbe muſt be vnderſtoode after the vſe of thinges in Iury. In this kyngdome onely groweth that precious oyntment called Balſamum, or balme. And oyntmentes among this people were eſteemed for the preciouſt thinges of the kingdome, as we may ſee in the bookes of the kynges. Wherfore this was a fit & apte prouerbe among the Iewes, but not
among other nations, with whom perhaps precious ſtones are in more price. This is therfore a metaphore. As a precious odour and ſmell delighteth ye noſe, ſo doth a good name delight the ſpiritual ſmell and fauour. This metaphore S. Paule commendeth 2. Corinth. 2. ſaying: We be the ſweete ſauour of Chriſt &c. For Paule was a good teacher, and ſincere preacher, and in his conuerſation faultles.

The meaning of this place.The meaning therfore of this place is: Be not ouercommed of anger. As I haue taught thée to ſtand in feare before God, ſo I teach thee to continue in good workes before men. For what though ſome be offēded and enuy at thy labours? continue thou ſtill on, and the good ſauour and good name, thou ſhalt get therby, ſhall allure thee more to apply & follow thy labour.

div.head: Better is the day of death, then the day of byrth.
div.p:
An exhortation to beare patiently the incōmodities of this life. I Thinke this alſo is ſpoken prouerbially. It ſéemeth to taſte of gentilitie, & the fleſhe, to preferre death before lyfe. But he ſpeaketh not ſimply of lyfe and death, but of ſuch thinges as are to be
done, and are done euen of ye wyſeſt mē. Shew me a man in office, or ruler of a houſe and familie, and let him ſay, if it were better to wiſhe death, then to liue in ſo many daungers and toyles? Salomō therefore compareth this life to himſelfe, and not to the lyfe to come, & ſaith: If we ſhall conſider the lyfe of man, then it is true that the day of death is better then the day of byrth. For what greater euil can happen to a man, then that thoſe which are in office, and doe all they can with all their hart for the behoofe of the common weale, and ſuffer whatſoeuer thinges for the common weales ſake, yet at the length finde nothing but all kynde of ingratefulnes, contempt, loſſe, baniſhment. &c.

Thus the texte is not ſimply to be vnderſtāded as it ſoūdeth, that he ſpeaketh not of Gods workes, nor of the lyfe that is after this lyfe, but of worldly matters as we vſe and handle them, whereof we receaue nothing but occaſions of anger & impatiencie. For the day of our byrth bringeth vs into theſe miſeries, & death deliuereth vs frō them. Mans byrth is a good thyng, and a creature of God: neyther
doth Salomon ſpeake thereof, but of the vſe of it. For as my natiuitie is the creature of God, and as I vſe it, they are thinges different. We of our natiuitie haue nothing but cares: not through our natiuities default, but through our own, and by reaſon of the naughtines of the worlde, which abuſeth the creatures of God. Euen ſo our lyfe, as it is the creature of God, belongeth not to this booke. For of it to ſay, death were better then it were a moſt impious thing, conſidering God hath made vs men, and would haue vs to liue.
